description: The Accelerated ICND1 show will present fundamental networking theory and helps prepare viewers not only for the exam but working knowledge of how to configure, verify and connect Cisco equipment in a working network. This show is presented at an accelerated pace and highly focused on exam objectives to help the viewer to review the exam objectives for the 100-105 exam.  It is a great way to check for exam readiness!
name: Accelerated CCENT
subtitle: Cisco Certified Entry Network Technician

episodes.description: The new ICND1 exam 100-105 is considered by Cisco to be the first exam that validates your skills as an entry level networking technician familiar with Cisco products, networking concepts and terminology. This exam tests a potential candidate's knowledge and skills in network fundamentals, Cisco LAN switching technologies, Cisco routing technologies, infrastructure services, and infrastructure administration and maintenance. The show will present fundamental theory and helps prepare viewers not only for the exam but working knowledge of how to configure, verify and connect cisco equipment in a working network.
episodes.title: Introduction to ICND1
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.006 --> 00:00:05.747
[SOUND]
Welcome

2
00:00:05.747 --> 00:00:11.010
to ITProTV.

3
00:00:11.010 --> 00:00:15.982
Today, we're here to introduce you
to the ICND1 content, right, for

4
00:00:15.982 --> 00:00:18.847
getting ready for Exam 100-105.

5
00:00:18.847 --> 00:00:22.669
And to help us to make sure that we
actually know what we're gonna be covering

6
00:00:22.669 --> 00:00:25.780
in this new show that we're
producing is Mr Todd Lammle.

7
00:00:25.780 --> 00:00:26.882
Thank you for joining us.

8
00:00:26.882 --> 00:00:30.330
>> Thank you, Ronnie,
it's good to be back here with ITProTV.

9
00:00:30.330 --> 00:00:33.370
I am very excited about this
episode we're about to create.

10
00:00:33.370 --> 00:00:37.623
We're about to do multiple episodes,
both for the ICND1 CCENT and

11
00:00:37.623 --> 00:00:42.420
then of course for the CCNA ICND2
section 2, different courses.

12
00:00:42.420 --> 00:00:45.878
So in this first course,
which we're about to jump into,

13
00:00:45.878 --> 00:00:49.351
we're gonna learn about inner
networking and Ethernet.

14
00:00:49.351 --> 00:00:51.635
And we're gonna spend some
time on Ethernet actually.

15
00:00:51.635 --> 00:00:55.361
We'll really get our foundations down pat,
TCP/IP, and

16
00:00:55.361 --> 00:01:00.700
then we're gonna hit subnetting,
VLSM, and summarization.

17
00:01:00.700 --> 00:01:03.760
All right, so maybe you feel really
comfortable with inner networking,

18
00:01:03.760 --> 00:01:08.950
Ethernet, TCP/IP, subnet, and VLSM and
summarization, and that's fine.

19
00:01:09.990 --> 00:01:13.440
But I highly recommend maybe
perusing through it and

20
00:01:13.440 --> 00:01:15.420
redoing and building up that foundation.

21
00:01:15.420 --> 00:01:17.100
It's kind of like going to the gym, right?

22
00:01:17.100 --> 00:01:21.350
Gotta go do some push ups, right,
get our subnetting down at least, right?

23
00:01:21.350 --> 00:01:23.060
No subnetting, no CCENT, right?

24
00:01:23.060 --> 00:01:25.110
No VLSM, no summarization, no CCENT, okay?

25
00:01:25.110 --> 00:01:29.919
Then we're gonna hit the CISCO IOS,
we're gonna log into some routers and

26
00:01:29.919 --> 00:01:34.803
switches, just basic stuff,
doing the help send, setting IP addresses,

27
00:01:34.803 --> 00:01:38.320
understanding CDP, and
managing the CISCO IOS.

28
00:01:38.320 --> 00:01:40.790
So we actually spent a lot of
time in managing CISCO IOS.

29
00:01:40.790 --> 00:01:47.141
So in this newer CCENT, based from 2016,
from the one that was from 2013, right?

30
00:01:47.141 --> 00:01:49.004
We got a new one in 2016.

31
00:01:49.004 --> 00:01:52.660
We have a lot more management
of the CISCO IOS, right?

32
00:01:52.660 --> 00:01:55.690
So although in the CISCO IOS chapter six,

33
00:01:55.690 --> 00:01:59.370
we're going to set our passwords,
crypt our passwords, and things like that.

34
00:01:59.370 --> 00:02:03.437
And we're going to then manage
the network with like Telnet SSH.

35
00:02:03.437 --> 00:02:07.063
And one of their bigger objectives
this time is DHP servers, right, and

36
00:02:07.063 --> 00:02:11.780
understanding DHCP servers, configuring
DHCP servers, controlling DHCP servers.

37
00:02:11.780 --> 00:02:13.150
So we're gonna spend some time,
and in my book,

38
00:02:13.150 --> 00:02:19.150
I talk about DHCP servers in three
different chapters, three different ways,

39
00:02:19.150 --> 00:02:23.180
that's how important this is,
DNS servers, understanding DNS servers.

40
00:02:23.180 --> 00:02:25.430
And then we're going to hit IP routing.

41
00:02:25.430 --> 00:02:26.960
This is a routing and switching course, so

42
00:02:26.960 --> 00:02:28.623
we're gonna spend some
time with IP routing.

43
00:02:28.623 --> 00:02:31.730
The CCENT doesn't have a huge
amount of objectives on routing.

44
00:02:31.730 --> 00:02:35.170
We have to understand how packets and
frames work, and

45
00:02:35.170 --> 00:02:39.210
the frames work locally to get
a packet to a router, for example, and

46
00:02:39.210 --> 00:02:42.040
the packets switch to another network and
put into another frame.

47
00:02:42.040 --> 00:02:43.210
We have to understand that process, and

48
00:02:43.210 --> 00:02:45.970
we'll go through it in detail in
the IP routing section, right?

49
00:02:45.970 --> 00:02:47.950
And then we also cover static and
default routing,

50
00:02:47.950 --> 00:02:51.930
that's pretty much most of the routing
objectives, configuration objectives.

51
00:02:51.930 --> 00:02:54.260
But we also then get into RIP version 2.

52
00:02:54.260 --> 00:02:58.690
So unlike the old CCENT 2013 objectives,
in the new objectives that had come out in

53
00:02:58.690 --> 00:03:02.720
2016, they just had RIP version
2 static and default routing.

54
00:03:02.720 --> 00:03:05.270
So we will make sure that we
understand that, passive interfaces.

55
00:03:05.270 --> 00:03:08.906
We'll go into a little bit more detail
than we have in the past in CCENT

56
00:03:08.906 --> 00:03:09.680
version 2.

57
00:03:09.680 --> 00:03:14.330
But then we're gonna get into switching,
layer two switching.

58
00:03:14.330 --> 00:03:19.270
And understanding how switches work,
how they forward filter and

59
00:03:19.270 --> 00:03:25.090
flood frames, and then we're gonna do
VLANs and access ports, trunk ports,

60
00:03:25.090 --> 00:03:31.360
inter VLAN routing with router on a stick,
and with a layer three switch, right?

61
00:03:31.360 --> 00:03:35.020
So, layer switch is probably the best way
to go today, but we have to know both for

62
00:03:35.020 --> 00:03:36.270
the objectives.

63
00:03:36.270 --> 00:03:39.594
Okay, then we're gonna hit security,
we're gonna talk about access list, and

64
00:03:39.594 --> 00:03:43.450
we only hit, [LAUGH] in the new CCENT,
we only talk about standard access list.

65
00:03:43.450 --> 00:03:48.140
So, they're pretty simple, actually,
but securing VTY lines, right?

66
00:03:48.140 --> 00:03:52.400
We're gonna make sure we do a lab on that,
and then we're gonna get into NAT, and

67
00:03:52.400 --> 00:03:56.170
we're gonna do configuration on
static dynamic NAT with the pool and

68
00:03:56.170 --> 00:03:58.660
then PAT or NAT overload.

69
00:03:58.660 --> 00:04:03.558
So we're gonna really hit NAT hard,
and then we're gonna finish up with

70
00:04:03.558 --> 00:04:07.433
a really big section,
a very exciting section on IPv6.

71
00:04:07.433 --> 00:04:09.210
So repeat after me.

72
00:04:09.210 --> 00:04:10.860
IPv6 is my friend.

73
00:04:10.860 --> 00:04:12.630
All right, so stick around.

74
00:04:12.630 --> 00:04:16.210
Don't leave until the end cuz
we have a big finale, all right?

75
00:04:16.210 --> 00:04:22.505
So, let's get started on CCENT, and we're
gonna jump right into inter networking.

76
00:04:22.505 --> 00:04:31.189
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd Lammle introduces us to the basic networking concepts and components.  These are important concepts that establish the foundational knowledge of internetworking.  The focus is on terminology and basic concepts that must be mastered for the exam.
episodes.title: Internetworking
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.347 --> 00:00:15.169
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV,

3
00:00:15.169 --> 00:00:16.593
I'm your host Ronnie Wang.

4
00:00:16.593 --> 00:00:17.288
And today,

5
00:00:17.288 --> 00:00:21.980
we're gonna be taking the Interconnecting
Cisco Networking Devices part 1.

6
00:00:21.980 --> 00:00:24.124
And we have with us in
the studio today Mr.

7
00:00:24.124 --> 00:00:27.801
Todd Lammle, who's gonna help make
sure that we are focused right in on

8
00:00:27.801 --> 00:00:31.445
those exam objectives in getting ready for
this new exam that's out.

9
00:00:31.445 --> 00:00:33.980
So Todd, welcome back to our studios.

10
00:00:33.980 --> 00:00:34.508
>> Thank you, very much.

11
00:00:34.508 --> 00:00:36.342
It's great to be here, guys.

12
00:00:36.342 --> 00:00:41.020
I'm gonna jump right into our first
episode, internetworking, define exciting

13
00:00:41.020 --> 00:00:45.800
terms like collision domains, broadcast
domains and even the term internetwork.

14
00:00:45.800 --> 00:00:47.300
So, let's go ahead and take a look.

15
00:00:47.300 --> 00:00:50.555
All right, on this one here,
we have the basic network and if you guys

16
00:00:50.555 --> 00:00:54.543
are following with my book, I use the same
figures throughout this video course that

17
00:00:54.543 --> 00:00:58.100
I will in my book, so you should be
able to follow along chapter by chapter.

18
00:00:58.100 --> 00:01:02.270
Now, that being said, Bob's gonna talk
to Sally, I use that analogy a lot.

19
00:01:02.270 --> 00:01:03.475
Sally doesn't really like Bob,

20
00:01:03.475 --> 00:01:05.973
as you'll find out as we go through
these episodes but nonetheless,

21
00:01:05.973 --> 00:01:08.788
Bob wants to communicate with Sally,
maybe get a file from her or something.

22
00:01:08.788 --> 00:01:13.772
So he'll use a file transfer protocol,
maybe we'll use FTP and

23
00:01:13.772 --> 00:01:17.430
he'll say hey, FTP Sally, you there?

24
00:01:17.430 --> 00:01:20.490
And really his host doesn't
even communicate to Sally,

25
00:01:20.490 --> 00:01:21.730
it has to do something first.

26
00:01:21.730 --> 00:01:22.654
What is that Ronnie, you think?

27
00:01:22.654 --> 00:01:25.210
>> We normally have to do
something called name resolution.

28
00:01:25.210 --> 00:01:27.075
>> Name resolution's like ding,
ding, ding.

29
00:01:27.075 --> 00:01:30.690
So, we have to and
DNS is pretty important.

30
00:01:30.690 --> 00:01:35.380
Now in the world where we're running
mostly IP Version 4 today as users,

31
00:01:35.380 --> 00:01:38.850
in our back ISPs we're using more IPV6.

32
00:01:38.850 --> 00:01:43.240
Saying something like TellMed or FTP
1.1.1.1 which is Sally's IP isn't a big

33
00:01:43.240 --> 00:01:47.110
deal, but being DNS becomes a much bigger
deal when we get tied to version 6.

34
00:01:47.110 --> 00:01:50.690
But also if we didn't have DNS,
we wouldn't be able to get to places on

35
00:01:50.690 --> 00:01:53.110
the Internet too, because we'd have to
know every IP address on the Internet,

36
00:01:53.110 --> 00:01:54.830
that could be a little cumbersome.

37
00:01:54.830 --> 00:01:59.150
None the less, DNS is gonna resolve
Sally's address to an IP address in this

38
00:01:59.150 --> 00:02:02.198
example something simple right, 1.1.1.1.

39
00:02:02.198 --> 00:02:07.820
Now, Bob has almost everything he
needs to use to communicate to Sally.

40
00:02:07.820 --> 00:02:10.450
He still needs to get her-
>> MAC address.

41
00:02:10.450 --> 00:02:11.085
>> MAC address.

42
00:02:11.085 --> 00:02:12.370
Thank you, very much.

43
00:02:12.370 --> 00:02:15.260
If we are on a LAN,
I don't communicate using IP address.

44
00:02:15.260 --> 00:02:17.830
I use that IP address to
get someone's MAC address,

45
00:02:17.830 --> 00:02:20.690
hardware address, burned-in address,
whatever you wanna call it.

46
00:02:20.690 --> 00:02:23.942
Nonetheless, Sally's going to send that,
or he's gonna look in his ARP cache.

47
00:02:23.942 --> 00:02:27.744
But when you get sent in a host, he's
gonna save that for I think Windows keeps

48
00:02:27.744 --> 00:02:31.740
it for about nine minutes, but Cisco
routers keep it for four hours, all right?

49
00:02:31.740 --> 00:02:37.672
So basically, now we're going to broadcast
an ARP address resolution protocol,

50
00:02:37.672 --> 00:02:41.838
get Sally's Mac at us,
now Bob can communicate to Sally.

51
00:02:41.838 --> 00:02:46.388
But on this basic network, we just created
connecting segments together here, so

52
00:02:46.388 --> 00:02:49.768
they can share resources like files,
printers and whatnot,

53
00:02:49.768 --> 00:02:52.820
that's why we created the basic network.

54
00:02:52.820 --> 00:02:58.280
So, in the basic network we have hubs,
and all they read is digital signal,

55
00:02:58.280 --> 00:03:02.060
work at something called layer one and
all we do is read the digital signals.

56
00:03:02.060 --> 00:03:05.620
Now, inside here we encode the ones and
zeroes, right.

57
00:03:05.620 --> 00:03:09.010
So in ethernet, we use something called
Manchester encoding, but we also use

58
00:03:09.010 --> 00:03:13.450
something called analog signalling today,
too and I'll show you that in a minute.

59
00:03:13.450 --> 00:03:16.580
But in this case here when
Bob sends a digital signal,

60
00:03:16.580 --> 00:03:18.990
the hubs don't segment the network.

61
00:03:18.990 --> 00:03:22.330
They just take that digital signal and
re-amplify and send it out or

62
00:03:22.330 --> 00:03:25.400
regenerate it and
send it out every port, right?

63
00:03:25.400 --> 00:03:27.780
So, this is considered
one big collision domain.

64
00:03:28.800 --> 00:03:31.978
Meaning that every device is
really just in one big network,

65
00:03:31.978 --> 00:03:35.793
cuz these wires are all just
interconnected together with this device.

66
00:03:35.793 --> 00:03:39.253
So, this is one big collision domain,
meaning that only one device can

67
00:03:39.253 --> 00:03:42.942
communicate at a time, and I think all
of us are aware that what happens if two

68
00:03:42.942 --> 00:03:45.720
device and
a digital signal at the same time.

69
00:03:45.720 --> 00:03:50.800
Now so, we're not going to really use hub
today, we're going to use LAN switches.

70
00:03:50.800 --> 00:03:54.450
Right, they came from bridges,
they break up collision domain.

71
00:03:54.450 --> 00:04:00.411
So, every port on the switch is
called his own collision domain.

72
00:04:00.411 --> 00:04:04.220
So now this allows us to have
more bandwidth for users.

73
00:04:04.220 --> 00:04:06.790
So in this case here,
when Bob wants to talk to Johnny,

74
00:04:06.790 --> 00:04:10.450
certainly broadcast,
getting his MAC address.

75
00:04:10.450 --> 00:04:14.780
Once he does that, he sends a frame
with a destination MAC address to John.

76
00:04:14.780 --> 00:04:18.310
It comes over here to the switch,
the switch doesn't have any destination

77
00:04:18.310 --> 00:04:21.630
port with that MAC address on it, or
any board with that MAC address on it.

78
00:04:21.630 --> 00:04:23.600
So, it doesn't forward it out any ports.

79
00:04:23.600 --> 00:04:28.636
So, Sally is very happy right now,
cuz she's not getting John's data anymore.

80
00:04:28.636 --> 00:04:34.258
Now in this case here, John wants to go to
the Internet and he sends it to a switch.

81
00:04:34.258 --> 00:04:37.060
And instead of like the hub where it
just takes that digital signal and

82
00:04:37.060 --> 00:04:40.360
sends out every port,
now we're only gonna send it out to port,

83
00:04:40.360 --> 00:04:43.160
the frame that's destined for,
in this case here it's destined for what?

84
00:04:43.160 --> 00:04:44.600
The default gateway,

85
00:04:44.600 --> 00:04:49.920
which is configured on John's host via
statically with an IP address or through,

86
00:04:49.920 --> 00:04:53.520
with probably typically through something
called DHCP which we will look at shortly.

87
00:04:53.520 --> 00:04:57.654
But it comes in here the source MAC
addresses look to make sure it's in

88
00:04:57.654 --> 00:05:00.518
the MAC address so
we know John's MAC address.

89
00:05:00.518 --> 00:05:04.324
The destination if we don't know it, we're
going to flood this frame now to every

90
00:05:04.324 --> 00:05:06.325
port that is looking for the destination.

91
00:05:06.325 --> 00:05:09.510
But in this case we know it, so
it really goes to port four.

92
00:05:09.510 --> 00:05:12.848
Again, the Cisco's term for micro
segmentation where every port beings its

93
00:05:12.848 --> 00:05:16.070
own collision domain really shows
its value here, doesn't it?

94
00:05:16.070 --> 00:05:19.560
Because we're not sending frames out,
ports where the data's not destined.

95
00:05:19.560 --> 00:05:21.890
We're saving bandwidth for users this way.

96
00:05:21.890 --> 00:05:23.956
However, but without routers,

97
00:05:23.956 --> 00:05:28.834
we might have multiple collision domains
here guys, but we're one big what?

98
00:05:28.834 --> 00:05:29.682
>> Broadcast domain.

99
00:05:29.682 --> 00:05:31.517
>> Broadcast domain.

100
00:05:31.517 --> 00:05:34.260
By default, okay?

101
00:05:34.260 --> 00:05:36.570
So, Bob's sitting here going,
I love it that everyone hears my data,

102
00:05:36.570 --> 00:05:39.700
but you're gonna learn that
Bob's kind of a jerk in my book.

103
00:05:39.700 --> 00:05:43.520
When I was at Hughes in the 90s,
he was an accountant, and he was a jerk.

104
00:05:43.520 --> 00:05:47.970
S, I've been using him in my books for
18 years, this poor Bob guy.

105
00:05:47.970 --> 00:05:50.246
Anyways, never piss off someone in IT.

106
00:05:50.246 --> 00:05:52.889
All right, anyways, I love shouting.

107
00:05:52.889 --> 00:05:56.840
And he sends it out, and
basically you hear Sally go man,

108
00:05:56.840 --> 00:05:58.760
I need to get away from this guy, right?

109
00:05:58.760 --> 00:06:01.930
So you can read more detail about Bob and
Sally in my book.

110
00:06:01.930 --> 00:06:03.880
That's should go and
make you go out and buy my book.

111
00:06:03.880 --> 00:06:07.100
The drama in networking that
you never knew existed.

112
00:06:07.100 --> 00:06:10.690
Remember, that Cisco calls
this micro segmentation.

113
00:06:10.690 --> 00:06:14.650
So in this case here, one big broadcast,
is our network better?

114
00:06:14.650 --> 00:06:17.980
Absolutely, better than the hub network,
but not good enough for today's network.

115
00:06:17.980 --> 00:06:20.320
Now we're gonna create a what?

116
00:06:20.320 --> 00:06:21.640
What's this section called?

117
00:06:21.640 --> 00:06:23.600
An internetwork.

118
00:06:24.740 --> 00:06:30.668
So, when we put out a router or some type
of, hold on guys, layer three device,

119
00:06:30.668 --> 00:06:35.610
right, so we can have an enterprise
switch that does this as well.

120
00:06:35.610 --> 00:06:37.355
Now, we're breaking up a broadcast domain.

121
00:06:37.355 --> 00:06:42.140
So when I look at this figure here,
I have two broadcast domains.

122
00:06:42.140 --> 00:06:45.720
One for each router interface and
I have multiple collision domains.

123
00:06:45.720 --> 00:06:50.640
This is one, two,
three collision domains on each side,

124
00:06:50.640 --> 00:06:54.910
one broadcast domain on each side, two
broadcast domains total in this figure,

125
00:06:54.910 --> 00:06:57.910
and there's,
looks like six collision domains.

126
00:06:57.910 --> 00:07:01.580
That being said, Bob sends a broadcast,
the router drops the broadcast,

127
00:07:01.580 --> 00:07:02.850
does not forward it by default.

128
00:07:02.850 --> 00:07:04.170
Can I forward that?

129
00:07:04.170 --> 00:07:05.692
Can I fix it to sort for its broadcast?

130
00:07:05.692 --> 00:07:08.599
Yeah, we'll do that later on,
but in this case here,

131
00:07:08.599 --> 00:07:12.790
we're gonna have collision domains,
now we have broadcast domains.

132
00:07:12.790 --> 00:07:15.175
This is where the term
internetworking comes in.

133
00:07:15.175 --> 00:07:19.351
Once we put a layer three device in,
now we have separate broadcast,

134
00:07:19.351 --> 00:07:24.608
means these are called subnets aren't
they, we're in IP version four, right.

135
00:07:24.608 --> 00:07:26.820
And Cicsco likes the term address base,
and

136
00:07:26.820 --> 00:07:30.750
the reason why is because I'm gonna
have an IPv4 network over here.

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd introduces the OSI model and explains it’s basic purpose, breakdown and PDU concepts.  The OSI was introduced when networking between disparate networks was more likely, Todd explains and then tells us where it’s particular usefulness may have passed.  Even so, Todd breaks down the 7 layers into the Upper Block and Lower Block introducing why we still use it today.  It’s main use is descriptive, essentially allowing us to understand how data is prepared for networking between endpoints.  He also describes how data is broken into PDUs called segments, packets and frames that help to get data to it’s destination.

in processes, that Cisco wants you
to really understand for the secant.

83
00:04:09.590 --> 00:04:10.570
You really have to understand this.

84
00:04:10.570 --> 00:04:14.290
I have this in multiple chapters in my
book explaining this in different ways.

85
00:04:14.290 --> 00:04:19.510
DNS gives us our name resolution right,
name to IP address resolution.

86
00:04:19.510 --> 00:04:21.660
If we did not have that today
we really could not communicate,

87
00:04:21.660 --> 00:04:23.050
it would be pretty tough.

88
00:04:23.050 --> 00:04:27.480
Right now we know from our earlier example
where Bob talked to Sally right, and

89
00:04:27.480 --> 00:04:30.320
we could use her IP address because it
is pretty easy with IP version 4, or

90
00:04:30.320 --> 00:04:34.800
easier But not to get to the internet; for
example, what's Cisco's IP address?

91
00:04:34.800 --> 00:04:38.760
You'd have to type in www the ip
address or just type in the IP address.

92
00:04:38.760 --> 00:04:41.990
So the point is, when we get to IPv6,
that's impossible, so

00:04:41.990 --> 00:04:44.150
DNS become extremely important.

94
00:04:44.150 --> 00:04:46.460
Now, what does DHCP do?

95
00:04:46.460 --> 00:04:48.290
It's been around for a long time, guys.

96
00:04:48.290 --> 00:04:52.771
And it started off in the late
70's/early 80's as boot:he,

97
00:04:52.771 --> 00:04:57.680
when we had disclose workstations and so
on, and DHP rides on top of boot:he today.

98
00:04:57.680 --> 00:05:00.610
Everyone says 'well,
it gives me my IP address', no no no,

99
00:05:00.610 --> 00:05:05.550
it gives you much more than that,
it gives IP configuration to host.

100
00:05:05.550 --> 00:05:10.110
IP, subnet mask,
default gateway, DNS, WINS.

101
00:05:10.110 --> 00:05:12.860
Option 43, if you know what that is,
that's vender specific information,

102
00:05:12.860 --> 00:05:18.130
so we can go way out there with DHCP,
more than most people would realize.

103
00:05:18.130 --> 00:05:23.450
Now, we have remember something called
DORA, so how does a client come up?

104
00:05:23.450 --> 00:05:26.520
First of all it comes up and says hey
Help me, I don't have an IP address,

105
00:05:26.520 --> 00:05:30.280
I'm a DHCP client, no one gave
me an IP address, I'm a nobody.

106
00:05:30.280 --> 00:05:30.820
Right?
So it

107
00:05:30.820 --> 00:05:36.520
sends out the source IP address of all
zeros and it sends this out as a discover.

108
00:05:36.520 --> 00:05:38.260
Right?
So we've got discover,

109
00:05:38.260 --> 00:05:41.150
then the server [INAUDIBLE] goes well,
I can offer you this.

110
00:05:41.150 --> 00:05:43.730
And for this long Right,
and it comes back and

111
00:05:43.730 --> 00:05:46.960
it goes, well, I've been using
this address, I'd prefer that, so

112
00:05:46.960 --> 00:05:50.600
it's going to request and then it's going
to come back and its gonna say okay, fine.

113
00:05:50.600 --> 00:05:57.180
And this is cool, I'm somebody now, I've
got an IP address, mask, gateway and more.

114
00:05:57.180 --> 00:05:59.180
I've got all that and how did it get it?

115
00:05:59.180 --> 00:06:01.190
With something called DORA.

116
00:06:01.190 --> 00:06:02.500
That's how you're gonna remember it.

117
00:06:02.500 --> 00:06:05.340
Discover, offer, request, acknowledge.

118
00:06:07.200 --> 00:06:10.230
The Transport Layer typically gives
us our reliable communication but

119
00:06:10.230 --> 00:06:14.400
I'm sure that as you're all aware it can
give us unreliable communication as well.

120
00:06:14.400 --> 00:06:17.350
Now we only use two protocols today.

121
00:06:17.350 --> 00:06:19.610
Ronnie, what do you think
those two protocols are?

122
00:06:19.610 --> 00:06:22.490
>> One is gonna be UDP and
the other one is TCP.

123
00:06:22.490 --> 00:06:23.010
>> That's right.

124
00:06:23.010 --> 00:06:24.620
I have them listed down here.

125
00:06:24.620 --> 00:06:28.420
There is UDP that's my connection less and

126
00:06:28.420 --> 00:06:33.860
TCP is my connection oriented gives us
a reliable session, not guaranteed but

127
00:06:33.860 --> 00:06:36.940
reliable, it's more reliable and
we'll talk about how that happens.

128
00:06:36.940 --> 00:06:40.470
So this is a the transport layer
there also something here called

129
00:06:40.470 --> 00:06:42.070
the Protocol Data Unit,

130
00:06:42.070 --> 00:06:46.910
this is nothing really it's just way to
define the data at any certain layer.

131
00:06:46.910 --> 00:06:50.730
The upper PDUs is called data
The transport layer, the PDU,

132
00:06:50.730 --> 00:06:52.820
when it gets a header, right?

133
00:06:52.820 --> 00:06:56.710
We get the piece of the data,
is called a segment, why?

134
00:06:56.710 --> 00:06:58.070
Because we're gonna take the data stream.

135
00:06:58.070 --> 00:07:03.110
We're gonna break it up so we can transmit
it on the network into smaller segments.

136
00:07:03.110 --> 00:07:06.780
Let's go ahead and take a look at
reliable network communication.

137
00:07:06.780 --> 00:07:08.850
That happens with TCP.

138
00:07:08.850 --> 00:07:16.270
So remember, no connection is guaranteed,
but it can be reliable if TCP is used.

139
00:07:16.270 --> 00:07:19.720
The reason UDP is there is to give
the application developer options.

140
00:07:19.720 --> 00:07:20.960
You don't got a choice guys.

141
00:07:20.960 --> 00:07:24.460
When you boot up you say, I think I'm
gonna use UDP today, cuz I'm in a hurry.

142
00:07:24.460 --> 00:07:27.970
Ike, you don't have that option,
it comes with the application you choose.

143
00:07:27.970 --> 00:07:31.080
So in this case here,
what a reliable session?

144
00:07:31.080 --> 00:07:33.530
A reliable session means
a virtual circuit is set up and

145
00:07:33.530 --> 00:07:36.430
we'll take a look at the virtual
session setup on the next screen, but

146
00:07:36.430 --> 00:07:39.370
in this case here, once that's set
up we get a reliable session and

147
00:07:39.370 --> 00:07:43.950
that gives me, and
that happens by sequencing.

148
00:07:43.950 --> 00:07:44.960
We're gonna number the segments.

149
00:07:44.960 --> 00:07:46.430
Because remember we're
taking the data stream,

150
00:07:46.430 --> 00:07:49.250
breaking it into smaller pieces for
transmission on the network.

151
00:07:49.250 --> 00:07:51.170
So we're going to sequence it.

152
00:07:51.170 --> 00:07:54.070
Then we're gonna do flow control, okay.

153
00:07:54.070 --> 00:07:56.440
That flow control happens on the receiver.

154
00:07:56.440 --> 00:07:58.940
This is important for your CCN objectives.

155
00:07:58.940 --> 00:08:04.690
The receiver can control the transmission
speed of the transmitter right,

156
00:08:04.690 --> 00:08:06.670
and slow it down if its
buffers are getting full.

157
00:08:06.670 --> 00:08:09.370
Because if its Receivers' buffers are
getting full, then we're gonna lose data

158
00:08:09.370 --> 00:08:11.980
and we're no longer reliable
cuz we're dropping packets.

159
00:08:11.980 --> 00:08:12.950
So flow control.

160
00:08:12.950 --> 00:08:17.270
Then after we receive everything, we're
going to acknowledge it based on my what

161
00:08:17.270 --> 00:08:21.320
is called window size,
which is part of my flow control, okay.

162
00:08:23.040 --> 00:08:24.590
Now so
we're gonna to send acknowledgement.

163
00:08:24.590 --> 00:08:25.830
So we have Okay,

164
00:08:25.830 --> 00:08:31.050
so first off we have to set up something
called port numbers, port numbers.

165
00:08:31.050 --> 00:08:31.800
at the transfer layer.

166
00:08:33.010 --> 00:08:34.420
And this defines a couple things.

167
00:08:34.420 --> 00:08:39.510
One is my source port number which I
randomly make up between a number range,

168
00:08:39.510 --> 00:08:41.370
and then my destination port
number is one I'm gonna do.

169
00:08:41.370 --> 00:08:46.070
So if I was doing FTP,
I would do Destination port would be 21.

170
00:08:46.070 --> 00:08:49.310
Talent would be 23,
HTP would be 80, and so on.

171
00:08:49.310 --> 00:08:52.500
Now, in that case,
now we're going to acknowledge this.

172
00:08:52.500 --> 00:08:56.950
And if I'm doing flow control and things
come in too fast, I'm gonna slow down

173
00:08:56.950 --> 00:09:01.080
the transmitter with my flow
control mechanism called windowing.

174
00:09:01.080 --> 00:09:01.610
Right?

175
00:09:01.610 --> 00:09:04.550
So we're gonna go ahead and
take a look at this one last thing,

176
00:09:04.550 --> 00:09:09.810
TCP provides synchronized communication
between the transmitter receivers and

177
00:09:09.810 --> 00:09:10.780
take a look at that.

178
00:09:10.780 --> 00:09:16.070
So when a sender come ups it
sends a sync pocket, right?

179
00:09:16.070 --> 00:09:21.502
So this is called three-way handshake,
a three-way handshake

180
00:09:24.280 --> 00:09:29.480
So we sync the receiver if it
agrees with the terms port numbers,

181
00:09:29.480 --> 00:09:33.200
flow control, sequence number,
windowing size.

182
00:09:33.200 --> 00:09:35.970
If it agrees with all that,
it's going to send back a sync app.

183
00:09:35.970 --> 00:09:38.210
It also might change the windowing size,

184
00:09:38.210 --> 00:09:40.840
if you look at an analyser you'll see
this happen, you'll see the sync.

185
00:09:40.840 --> 00:09:45.680
The SYN/ACK comes back and says, I like
everything but the window size is too big.

186
00:09:45.680 --> 00:09:48.440
So I'm gonna recommend something else.

187
00:09:48.440 --> 00:09:52.570
And then the sender then gets that and
says, okay, I agree with all your terms.

188
00:09:52.570 --> 00:09:54.340
Let's create a session.

189
00:09:54.340 --> 00:09:57.990
Now we can't transmit any segments
until this session is complete.

190
00:09:57.990 --> 00:10:00.600
All right, that's the TCP 3-way handshake.

191
00:10:00.600 --> 00:10:05.200
All right and at the network layer we
have something called routed protocols.

192
00:10:05.200 --> 00:10:08.130
You've heard of this routed protocols.

193
00:10:08.130 --> 00:10:11.790
An example of routed protocols is IP which

194
00:10:11.790 --> 00:10:14.770
refers to IP version
four if you just say IP.

195
00:10:14.770 --> 00:10:18.290
The other routed protocol
we have here is IPV six.

196
00:10:18.290 --> 00:10:23.850
Now both of these are routed protocols
that are defined as Logical addressing and

197
00:10:23.850 --> 00:10:25.010
routing through an Internet network.

198
00:10:25.010 --> 00:10:28.810
So both of these,
you wanna think of as mailmen.

199
00:10:28.810 --> 00:10:33.900
So they're going to look at the routing
table, they're going to provide logical

200
00:10:33.900 --> 00:10:37.780
addressing, read logical addressing, and
do routing through an Internet network.

201
00:10:37.780 --> 00:10:39.630
So now we have, if you look at this,

202
00:10:39.630 --> 00:10:43.480
we have data coming down here to the
transport layer which gives us segments.

203
00:10:45.380 --> 00:10:46.980
Which comes down to the network layer, but

204
00:10:46.980 --> 00:10:52.060
now we have our protocol data
unit is called a packet.

205
00:10:52.060 --> 00:10:52.880
A packet.

206
00:10:52.880 --> 00:10:57.150
So IP is defined here as your well ware,
but we also have something called ICMP.

207
00:10:58.250 --> 00:11:02.030
Very important for
what diagnostics and, for example,

208
00:11:02.030 --> 00:11:04.480
what would be used here for diagnostics?

209
00:11:04.480 --> 00:11:08.450
I know what you're thinking,
ping and trace route, or just trace.

210
00:11:08.450 --> 00:11:12.300
And Microsoft uses TRACERT,
but it's not the same.

211
00:11:12.300 --> 00:11:15.700
That wasn't work on a Cisco router so we
won't answer that on a Cisco exam, right?

212
00:11:15.700 --> 00:11:19.580
All right, so ping and trace, but
we also get destination unreachables.

213
00:11:19.580 --> 00:11:21.140
Destination unreachables.

214
00:11:21.140 --> 00:11:24.200
Now a router works at the network layer,
doesn't it?

215
00:11:24.200 --> 00:11:28.240
So we're gonna have our, these are our
broadcaster mains, here and here.

216
00:11:28.240 --> 00:11:30.210
Right?
So we have two broadcast domains here,

217
00:11:30.210 --> 00:11:31.760
each with 2 subnets.

218
00:11:31.760 --> 00:11:35.000
And then we possibly could
have serial WAN connections,

219
00:11:35.000 --> 00:11:39.410
you absolutely have to have a serial WAN,
a router to do this.

220
00:11:39.410 --> 00:11:42.660
It's very rare in today's networks
that we still see serial WAN's.

221
00:11:42.660 --> 00:11:45.820
There's some out there, but I go to a lot
of my customers that just don't have it

222
00:11:45.820 --> 00:11:49.520
anymore because they're running MPLS or
PGP and so on, and so

223
00:11:49.520 --> 00:11:54.100
we have our LAN connections going
across our LAN, so we need PNs, right?

224
00:11:54.100 --> 00:11:57.760
But there is some, when we get to
the WAN section in ICD2, not ICD1.

225
00:11:57.760 --> 00:12:01.280
We are going to have some
serial connections in there.

226
00:12:01.280 --> 00:12:04.760
We just don't have the same as
what we had in the last CCA.

227
00:12:04.760 --> 00:12:09.530
So remember each router LAN
interface is a broadcast domain.

228
00:12:10.780 --> 00:12:15.650
Routers break up broadcast domains
by filtering on Layer 3 information.

229
00:12:17.280 --> 00:12:22.610
And also what's very important here is if
a broadcast comes in from Bob it's not.

230
00:12:22.610 --> 00:12:25.760
Forward to the cross router to
any other interface is dropped.

231
00:12:25.760 --> 00:12:27.610
Very important to understand.

232
00:12:27.610 --> 00:12:29.980
At the data link layer, remember,
let's go through this again.

233
00:12:29.980 --> 00:12:30.990
We had data up here.

234
00:12:32.390 --> 00:12:34.340
Send the data stream down
to the transport layer.

235
00:12:36.340 --> 00:12:39.375
From the transport layer we send
it down to the network layer.

236
00:12:39.375 --> 00:12:44.356
[COUGH] And

237
00:12:44.356 --> 00:12:47.130
so we get to data,
what's at the transport layer?

238
00:12:47.130 --> 00:12:50.390
Then we're gonna have what, segments.

239
00:12:50.390 --> 00:12:51.880
At the network layer we have what?

240
00:12:51.880 --> 00:12:52.390
>> Packets.

241
00:12:52.390 --> 00:12:59.110
>> Packets, okay, so now we come down to
the data link layer and we have what?

242
00:13:00.750 --> 00:13:01.990
Frames, frames.

243
00:13:01.990 --> 00:13:03.240
So the PDU is frames.

244
00:13:03.240 --> 00:13:05.740
Because we're gonna take the packet,
so if this is my packet, I'm

245
00:13:08.230 --> 00:13:12.630
gonna put a header in there and
a trailer, kind of like bookends, so

246
00:13:12.630 --> 00:13:16.280
we're going to encapsulate
the frame with control information.

247
00:13:16.280 --> 00:13:19.070
In the header we'll find
out the next episode

248
00:13:19.070 --> 00:13:21.510
what's in that header
in this ethernet frame.

249
00:13:21.510 --> 00:13:23.070
But now that we have this,
we have a frame,

250
00:13:23.070 --> 00:13:26.000
now we send it down to the physical layer.

251
00:13:27.490 --> 00:13:32.090
Cuz this is sent out in bytes,
to be put into bits, and

252
00:13:32.090 --> 00:13:36.785
encoded within a digital or analog signal.

253
00:13:36.785 --> 00:13:39.206
[SOUND] Right.

254
00:13:39.206 --> 00:13:42.519
Now one last thing guys for
your objectives, for your CN objectives so

255
00:13:42.519 --> 00:13:44.000
pay attention here.

256
00:13:44.000 --> 00:13:47.100
You have your physical and
logical topologies.

257
00:13:47.100 --> 00:13:48.130
Now let's define these.

258
00:13:48.130 --> 00:13:52.380
A physical topology is the actual
cable layout in your network.

259
00:13:53.410 --> 00:13:56.310
The logical topology is defined

260
00:13:56.310 --> 00:14:00.450
As the digital signal that
traverses that physical topology.

261
00:14:00.450 --> 00:14:02.180
They can be different.

262
00:14:02.180 --> 00:14:06.710
For example here, if I look at this bus
topology here, I have a physical bus, and

263
00:14:06.710 --> 00:14:08.970
then my signal is gonna
travel down the wire,

264
00:14:08.970 --> 00:14:13.240
stop at in this location,
just like a bus going down a street.

265
00:14:13.240 --> 00:14:15.770
We have the ring topology, we have token.

266
00:14:15.770 --> 00:14:20.840
Now I pretty much only see these in
large metro ethernet with like Sonnet or

267
00:14:20.840 --> 00:14:22.100
something today.

268
00:14:22.100 --> 00:14:26.150
I don't see too much Mesh but
Mesh gives us the most flexibility and

269
00:14:26.150 --> 00:14:30.030
redundancy and then but
we usually use a star topology.

270
00:14:30.030 --> 00:14:33.540
This is also refered to as a hybrid,
isn't it?

271
00:14:33.540 --> 00:14:34.730
A hybrid technology.

272
00:14:34.730 --> 00:14:39.450
The hybrid is, basically, we have on
physical topology But we have a different

273
00:14:39.450 --> 00:14:43.550
type of, one physical topology but
a different type of logical topology.

274
00:14:43.550 --> 00:14:45.840
So our networks today
are physical stars right,

275
00:14:45.840 --> 00:14:49.530
think about switches the wires coming
from all directions, logical bus.

276
00:14:49.530 --> 00:14:51.079
Because that's the way ethernet runs.

277
00:14:52.550 --> 00:14:55.940
All right Todd, well thank you again for
that introduction to the OSI model.

278
00:14:55.940 --> 00:14:59.290
And reminding us of all the things
that we need to be concerned about.

279
00:14:59.290 --> 00:15:02.890
Great thing again that Todd actually
reminded us is that on the OSI model,

280
00:15:02.890 --> 00:15:05.800
especially for the exam,
is not as big of a focus but

281
00:15:05.800 --> 00:15:07.500
it doesn't mean it's not important.

282
00:15:07.500 --> 00:15:10.590
So we wanna make sure that we do
pay attention to the OSI model,

283
00:15:10.590 --> 00:15:14.630
is break down into it's
PDU components as well.

284
00:15:14.630 --> 00:15:17.870
And also pay attention to those brief
protocols, especially in the transport

285
00:15:17.870 --> 00:15:22.720
layer, and of course in the network layer,
and in the datalink layer as well.

286
00:15:22.720 --> 00:15:25.380
These are actually great things
that we have to think about.

287
00:15:25.380 --> 00:15:26.360
And lastly here, Tom,

288
00:15:26.360 --> 00:15:30.610
remind us of the basic type of topologies,
being able to distinguish between physical

289
00:15:30.610 --> 00:15:35.250
topologies as well as logical topologies
is also going to be important there too.

290
00:15:35.250 --> 00:15:38.890
So in that sense there is a great
bit of information here but

291
00:15:38.890 --> 00:15:42.610
we're actually nicely
packaged in this one episode.

292
00:15:42.610 --> 00:15:47.700
Than you again Tod for helping us here,
thank you for joining us, signing of

IT Pro TV I'm your host Ronnie Wong
>> Tod Lemley

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd Lammle introduces TCP/IP the protocol suite used in internetworking today.  He compares it to OSI model and then focuses in on the transport layer and internet layer of the TCP/IP model. Todd also describes the headers used in TCP and UDP and differentiates between them.  Also he helps differentiate between broadcast, multicast and unicast traffic emphasizing the header information used during data transmission.

172.31.

So 172.16 to 31 is is reserved.

478

What do this reserved

479

>> Private address ranges one we
can use inside our own network but

480
00:25:11.030 --> 00:25:15.020
they are not allowed for
us to be able to use on the internet Yes.

481
00:25:15.020 --> 00:25:18.440
And that allowed to what extend
the life of IP Version 4.

482
00:25:18.440 --> 00:25:22.480
So I don't know if we should
hate this guy or love this guy.

483
00:25:22.480 --> 00:25:23.930
Right?
Because let me tell you,

484
00:25:23.930 --> 00:25:27.110
had they not come out with this, and
really it wasn't necessarily this.

485
00:25:27.110 --> 00:25:30.420
But it was this and Nad, or
pad address translation.

486
00:25:30.420 --> 00:25:31.610
That ruined our lives.

487
00:25:31.610 --> 00:25:35.870
And I say that because IP version
4 sucks as you're well aware, And

488
00:25:35.870 --> 00:25:39.700
the other, and
it extended the life of IP version four.

489
00:25:39.700 --> 00:25:43.250
Our world would be a lot better if we were
at IP version six, it absolutely would be.

490
00:25:43.250 --> 00:25:46.020
And we'll find out so stick around for
that later episode so

491
00:25:46.020 --> 00:25:47.650
you can find out what I'm talking about.

492
00:25:47.650 --> 00:25:50.799
In the class C it's anything
that starts with 192.168.

493
00:25:50.799 --> 00:25:55.310
I'm pretty sure that most people
watching this probably know this, and

494
00:25:55.310 --> 00:25:56.500
if not you do now.

495
00:25:56.500 --> 00:26:00.560
RC1918, which makes my public address
range as the numbers in between,

496
00:26:00.560 --> 00:26:03.960
one through nine,
11 through 126, and so on.

497
00:26:03.960 --> 00:26:07.680
Now, private IP addresses cannot
be routed through the Internet.

498
00:26:09.210 --> 00:26:12.880
They were a scheme to
conserve public addresses.

499
00:26:12.880 --> 00:26:17.310
But as I just mentioned, You can have this
if you don't have another translation

500
00:26:17.310 --> 00:26:21.620
protocol called
Network Address Translation, NAT, right?

501
00:26:21.620 --> 00:26:25.380
And because of NAT,
we extended our lives for a long time.

502
00:26:25.380 --> 00:26:29.410
Now that being said,
let's go ahead and take a look at,

503

I wanna show you guys a couple
of things before we move on.

504
00:26:37.930 --> 00:26:38.430
Okay?

505
00:26:39.480 --> 00:26:43.800
First off, IP Config is going
to show me my IP Address.

506
00:26:45.080 --> 00:26:47.930
All right?
So I can see my IP Address,

507
00:26:47.930 --> 00:26:51.130
192168 my default gateway and my mask.

508

I don't see my DNS server, though,
remember that was pretty important because

510
00:26:57.130 --> 00:27:00.900
So I might have to type in something else

What is this stuff down here?

512
00:27:01.780 --> 00:27:04.180
What is this weird address here,
looks like some alien thing.

>> That looks like an IPV6.

514
00:27:05.550 --> 00:27:06.350
>> It is.

515
00:27:06.350 --> 00:27:10.460
And not to jump ahead to far,
but what kind of IPV6 is that?

That's a link local.

517
00:27:11.400 --> 00:27:15.770
>> Yes, also it's a analogous

518

Right?
So we just get that automatically.

519
00:27:17.420 --> 00:27:18.940
It helps us communicate.

520
00:27:18.940 --> 00:27:23.070
So that's the hop hip of the IPV 6 world.

521
00:27:23.070 --> 00:27:26.650
Okay?
So I'm gonna do IPV config, oops,

space all and
that would get a lot more stuff here.

525

[LAUGH] Okay.

527
00:27:43.580 --> 00:27:45.500
>> Here, here, I'm getting there.

528

529
00:27:46.290 --> 00:27:49.270
Hooo That's some information there.

530

Okay IPV six, autoconfiguration,

Even tell us right there to link

My IPV four address and
then here's my DHCP server And

00:28:03.140 --> 00:28:05.070
here's my DNS servers, right.

534
00:28:05.070 --> 00:28:09.450
So we can see this with an IP config and
if I was on a Mac, so if I went over to my

535
00:28:09.450 --> 00:28:13.090
Mac, which I could do but
I'm not going to, what would I type in?

00:28:13.780 --> 00:28:15.710
>> For my Mac side or Linux.

540

>> IF config.
>> And

541
00:28:19.540 --> 00:28:21.890
then I'm gonna show you guys one
more thing that was important and

542
00:28:21.890 --> 00:28:24.970
I'm showing this cuz
>> It was on the objectives so

543
00:28:24.970 --> 00:28:25.920
when I was looking through,

00:28:25.920 --> 00:28:29.980
I'm I gotta go through this even though

00:28:29.980 --> 00:28:36.190
Local area connection, so this is my

And there's my properties here,

Let's take a look at my

548

My gosh, how am I at work and

549
00:28:47.120 --> 00:28:50.030
I mentioned I was using wireless
earlier and I'm not because I'm so

used to it because I'm a DHCP client here.

551

So let me test you guys
from the last episode.

552
00:28:55.260 --> 00:28:57.210
No let's test this guy over here.

553
00:28:57.210 --> 00:29:00.100
What happens when my host comes up and
doesn't have IPv4 address?

554

what's it gonna do?
>> It's

555

gonna do the discover process to Dora.

556
00:29:03.280 --> 00:29:05.530
>> Yes, go ahead and please elaborate.

557

>> On Dora?

558
00:29:06.430 --> 00:29:11.210
We of course, the client,
sends out a discover packet and

559

then the server of course gives us an
offer and then we reply with a request or

560
00:29:15.900 --> 00:29:17.980
if we actually do request-
>> Yeah we request.

561

>> And the finally it acknowledges saying
sure of course you can use that address.

562

>> Yeah
>> I never knew watching Dora the Explorer

>> [LAUGH]
>> But now we know how the DHP layer,

565

4 step process works, right?

566
00:29:32.110 --> 00:29:34.350
So in here then we're going to see,

Some people come in here and add it.

One of the things you got

sometimes they do troubleshooting

is someone comes in here and puts in 5678-
>> [LAUGH]

571

>> Or something like that.

572

And they're like you can't resolve names,
the DHP sent it out,

573

and its because someone came in here and

574

put a static address in here which would
absolutely make it stop working, right?

575

So we wanna be aware of
something like that,

576

which is why I went out of
the way to show you guys this.

577

>> All right, well thank you Todd again.

for actually taking us through
a little bit of the basics of

TCP/IP Remember that what we've

Right?
It was just a brief comparison versus

581

the OSI model and that DOD model.

582

Sometimes you also hear
the term TCPIP model as well.

583

And then Todd also ended taking us
through of course the breakdown here of

584

TCP as well as IVP, allowing us to look
at each of those Header layers and

585

the information inside.

586
00:30:27.810 --> 00:30:31.560
Focusing in on the idea here of
what makes reliable traffic and

587

of course unreliable as well.

588
00:30:33.630 --> 00:30:38.510
We also, of course, talked about the
multicast versus broadcast, and unicast,

589
00:30:38.510 --> 00:30:42.290
making sure that we understood that too,
and then of course the IP addressing,

590

making sure you understand the How those
break down as far as the classes go,

591

focusing in also on the RFC
1918 addresses, and

the private IP address range too.

So all these of course are important

They may not hit you just

And you just have to know if you're gonna

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd explains and demonstrates his signature method of subnetting quickly.  He emphasizes the importance of being able to do this quickly and accurately.  This skill set according to Todd is indicator of readiness for the ICND1 exam.  He takes us through multiple examples and even some different types of questions that are based on understanding the concept of subnetting. **Errata - at the 46:36 mark, Ronnie incorrectly names 212 as the next number in the sequence. The correct number is 208
episodes.title: Easy Subnetting
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.078 --> 00:00:10.078
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.078 --> 00:00:14.930
Welcome to another exciting
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.930 --> 00:00:20.170
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and
today we're taking a look at ICND1.

4
00:00:20.170 --> 00:00:22.670
We're specifically going to be
focusing on the exam objectives,

5
00:00:22.670 --> 00:00:25.380
and who better to help us than Mr.
Todd Lammle.

6
00:00:25.380 --> 00:00:27.340
Thank you for
being in the studios with us today.

7
00:00:27.340 --> 00:00:28.000
>> Excellent, Ronnie.

8
00:00:28.000 --> 00:00:28.560
OK, guys.

9
00:00:28.560 --> 00:00:30.220
We're going to start having some real fun.

10
00:00:30.220 --> 00:00:34.420
I know we've had some fun so
far in the previous episodes, but

11
00:00:34.420 --> 00:00:39.080
let's step into subnetting, but I'm going
to skip the details of subnetting and

12
00:00:39.080 --> 00:00:40.370
get right into easy subnetting.

13
00:00:40.370 --> 00:00:41.970
Does that sound good for you guys?

14
00:00:41.970 --> 00:00:43.900
All right let's go ahead and
take a look at this.

15
00:00:43.900 --> 00:00:45.380
All right, so I have done this a lot.

16
00:00:45.380 --> 00:00:49.580
So the one thing is I love getting in to
this section on my classes or whatever,

17
00:00:49.580 --> 00:00:53.310
but when I say you know
I don't cover binary,

18
00:00:53.310 --> 00:00:55.562
I don't use binary then
I show the screen right.

19
00:00:55.562 --> 00:00:59.360
[LAUGH] So this is kind of funny, but
here's the thing you wanna realize that

20
00:00:59.360 --> 00:01:03.610
why I'm showing you this screen cuz I
want you to see this pattern here, right.

21
00:01:03.610 --> 00:01:10.150
The pattern is, and the reason if we use
a regular mask, and we can't skip bits.

22
00:01:10.150 --> 00:01:13.480
And when we can't skip bits that
means our answers can't change.

23
00:01:13.480 --> 00:01:15.810
So, when we get into OSPF and
access list, so

24
00:01:15.810 --> 00:01:18.360
that we can use inverse mass,
then we just get bits.

25
00:01:18.360 --> 00:01:19.620
That makes it a little more complicated.

26
00:01:19.620 --> 00:01:24.280
In this case here, something that's really
simple when you understand that the math

27
00:01:24.280 --> 00:01:28.870
never changes, the answers can never
change, because we can't skip bits is why.

28
00:01:28.870 --> 00:01:31.180
So if we take a look, and
this is our subnet mask.

29
00:01:31.180 --> 00:01:36.140
So if you think about this
as our subnet mask, and

30
00:01:36.140 --> 00:01:39.810
for sake of argument to not stress people
out, it really doesn't matter here.

31
00:01:39.810 --> 00:01:43.220
But let's just say I'm in
the fourth octet doing a class C,

32
00:01:43.220 --> 00:01:44.665
that just helps people feel better.

33
00:01:44.665 --> 00:01:47.460
[LAUGH] So I'm in the fourth octet,
but the answers,

34
00:01:47.460 --> 00:01:50.530
whatever I'm doing here works in
the second, third, and fourth octet.

35
00:01:50.530 --> 00:01:54.240
But just to not stress and cause extra
anxiety, which this seems to do,

36
00:01:54.240 --> 00:01:58.310
we'll say we're class E, we're only
working in the fourth octet, okay?

37
00:01:58.310 --> 00:01:59.410
Keep it simple.

38
00:01:59.410 --> 00:02:04.190
So if I have no bits on in
my pseudo fourth octet here.

39
00:02:04.190 --> 00:02:05.337
Then my decimal value is 0.

40
00:02:05.337 --> 00:02:08.472
It would be 255, 255, 255, 0, right?

41
00:02:08.472 --> 00:02:13.210
If I turn on the first bit,
then I have a value of 128.

42
00:02:13.210 --> 00:02:17.620
So it would be 255, 255, 255, 128, right?

43
00:02:17.620 --> 00:02:21.130
So, the key is that and
we look at this, and

44
00:02:21.130 --> 00:02:26.540
as I turn on bits and don't skip bits,
these become my subnet masks.

45
00:02:26.540 --> 00:02:30.330
So I have the 128 mask, and we're
gonna go through what all that means.

46
00:02:30.330 --> 00:02:32.230
But I'm just getting you to
memorize the masks right now,

47
00:02:32.230 --> 00:02:35.492
because these masks never change,
they stay the same forever.

48
00:02:35.492 --> 00:02:39.150
[LAUGH] And if I have two bits on,
because I can't skip bits so

49
00:02:39.150 --> 00:02:43.650
I need more sub bits, so I add more sub
nit bits which take away the host bits.

50
00:02:43.650 --> 00:02:44.270
All right.

51
00:02:44.270 --> 00:02:47.680
So I have two bits, 128 and 64 equals 192.

52
00:02:47.680 --> 00:02:53.440
128, 64 and 32 equals 224.

53
00:02:53.440 --> 00:02:59.540
128 64 is 192, plus 32 is 224,
plus 16 is 240,

54
00:02:59.540 --> 00:03:05.460
plus 8 is 248, and this is the 4 bit.

55
00:03:05.460 --> 00:03:07.530
248 plus 4 is 252.

56
00:03:07.530 --> 00:03:11.640
Now that's how we get our subnet mask,
and then we can determine

57
00:03:11.640 --> 00:03:16.640
our subnets from these, and our
broadcasts, and our valid host addresses.

58
00:03:16.640 --> 00:03:21.018
Now on this case here, for right now,
since I told you we were doing a Class E,

59
00:03:21.018 --> 00:03:26.330
[COUGH]
I can only use six subnet masks.

60
00:03:26.330 --> 00:03:31.240
The last two maths listed here, I can't
use because they only have two host beds

61
00:03:31.240 --> 00:03:34.010
and if I took that away,
I mean you have to have two host beds.

62
00:03:34.010 --> 00:03:38.390
If I use the last two subnet mask here,
I would have one host bed and

63
00:03:38.390 --> 00:03:40.280
zero host beds respectively.

64
00:03:40.280 --> 00:03:44.950
So the fact is is that I want I'm going to
only have six mass that even makes it even

65
00:03:44.950 --> 00:03:48.920
easier which is another reason people like
classy, because there's less to memorize.

66
00:03:48.920 --> 00:03:51.660
You only have to memorize six things.

67
00:03:51.660 --> 00:03:55.060
Okay so let's take this mass that
we learned that could never change.

68
00:03:55.060 --> 00:03:57.200
So remember these numbers forever,

69
00:03:57.200 --> 00:04:00.030
because they can never change
in IP version four right?

70
00:04:00.030 --> 00:04:02.230
So now what do we do with these numbers?

71
00:04:02.230 --> 00:04:06.024
Well from these numbers we need to get
the subnet, the broadcast address, and

72
00:04:06.024 --> 00:04:08.450
between these two numbers
is my valid host range.

73
00:04:08.450 --> 00:04:09.980
Let's take a look.

74
00:04:09.980 --> 00:04:15.010
In this case here, we want to get
what's called our block size.

75
00:04:15.010 --> 00:04:20.320
I figured this out in the early to
mid 90s, how this block size worked.

76
00:04:20.320 --> 00:04:21.700
It just came to me, and

77
00:04:21.700 --> 00:04:25.100
then my whole career kind of
changed because of this right here.

78
00:04:25.100 --> 00:04:29.320
The reality is my career is where it
is because of what I figured out here.

79
00:04:29.320 --> 00:04:33.200
Because then, you're talking about
the mid 90s, when no one could subnet.

80
00:04:33.200 --> 00:04:35.450
And not only could I subnet in my head,
I could do VLSM and

81
00:04:35.450 --> 00:04:36.950
summarization in my head.

82
00:04:36.950 --> 00:04:39.230
It was obviously worth some money.

83
00:04:39.230 --> 00:04:43.505
But anyways, so basically I
figured out you have 256 numbers,

84
00:04:43.505 --> 00:04:45.630
because it's 0 to 255, guys.

85
00:04:45.630 --> 00:04:46.370
That's 256 numbers.

86
00:04:47.790 --> 00:04:53.430
So you take the 256 numbers minus
the mask, this is one bit on isn't it?

87
00:04:53.430 --> 00:04:57.020
And then we get something
called our block size.

88
00:04:57.020 --> 00:05:01.520
Now a block size is important because,
it's going to tell us our subnets.

89
00:05:01.520 --> 00:05:04.960
So I'll count in this
block size starting at 0.

90
00:05:04.960 --> 00:05:06.420
And we'll talk about
where we start at zero,

91
00:05:06.420 --> 00:05:09.860
but starting at zero all the way
up to 256 which is invalid.

92
00:05:09.860 --> 00:05:11.610

00:49:07.763 --> 00:49:08.798
That's what I've got here.

1049
00:49:08.798 --> 00:49:12.733
And on a /30, what do you guys think?

1050
00:49:12.733 --> 00:49:14.161
With a 113?

1051
00:49:16.788 --> 00:49:22.430
>> It would be 112, 116,
115, would be the broadcast.

1052
00:49:22.430 --> 00:49:24.340
>> That's right and we did it.

1053
00:49:24.340 --> 00:49:25.160
Okay?

1054
00:49:25.160 --> 00:49:26.640
Couple more questions guys.

1055
00:49:26.640 --> 00:49:31.564
What is the network address for
the host with IP address 190,

1056
00:49:31.564 --> 00:49:35.223
whoops, 192.168 23.61/28.

1057
00:49:35.223 --> 00:49:36.937
Should be able to knock this one out.

1058
00:49:36.937 --> 00:49:39.197
This is a kind of CCENT question here,
guys.

1059
00:49:39.197 --> 00:49:40.021
Knock it out of the park.

1060
00:49:40.021 --> 00:49:40.834
Do it for me.

1061
00:49:47.243 --> 00:49:51.540
192.168.23.61/28 is what mask?

1062
00:49:51.540 --> 00:49:57.520
It's a 240 mask in the fourth octet,
so block size of 16,

1063
00:49:57.520 --> 00:50:00.705
0, 32, 48, 64, I'm in the 48 subnet.

1064
00:50:01.920 --> 00:50:04.743
Next one's 64, so 63's my broadcast.

1065
00:50:04.743 --> 00:50:07.704
49 to 62 is my valid host.

1066
00:50:07.704 --> 00:50:08.668
Okay, that's how you do it.

1067
00:50:08.668 --> 00:50:10.189
That's how you have to do it.

1068
00:50:10.189 --> 00:50:14.007
Okay, a small company has
a Class C network address and

1069
00:50:14.007 --> 00:50:19.050
needs to create five subnets,
each accommodating 25 hosts.

1070
00:50:19.050 --> 00:50:20.560
Which subnet mask needs to be configured?

1071
00:50:23.910 --> 00:50:26.755
It's actually a pretty
relatively simple question.

1072
00:50:26.755 --> 00:50:28.205
>> [LAUGH]
>> What you guys wanna look for

1073
00:50:28.205 --> 00:50:30.850
is the amount of hosts and
get your block size.

1074
00:50:30.850 --> 00:50:32.197
So how many hosts do you have?

1075
00:50:32.197 --> 00:50:33.857
>> 25.

1076
00:50:33.857 --> 00:50:36.295
>> Which means you need a block size of?

1077
00:50:36.295 --> 00:50:36.886
>> 30.

1078
00:50:36.886 --> 00:50:38.245
>> 32.

1079
00:50:38.245 --> 00:50:39.581
Which is a mask of?

1080
00:50:39.581 --> 00:50:40.382
>> 224.

1081
00:50:40.382 --> 00:50:42.321
>> 224, there's your answer.

1082
00:50:42.321 --> 00:50:43.284
That's it.

1083
00:50:43.284 --> 00:50:47.984
Just look for the amount of hosts,
add it to your block size, get your host.

1084
00:50:47.984 --> 00:50:53.707
What is the subnet of 192.168.1.42,
that's a slash, 29.

1085
00:50:53.707 --> 00:50:54.705
I don't wanna read out the mask.

1086
00:50:54.705 --> 00:50:56.226
I'm lazy that way.

1087
00:50:56.226 --> 00:50:57.352
What do you guys think?

1088
00:50:57.352 --> 00:50:58.804
What sum is this host in?

1089
00:50:58.804 --> 00:51:00.243
>> 40.

1090
00:51:00.243 --> 00:51:03.471
>> Yeah, 40 broadcast is what?

1091
00:51:03.471 --> 00:51:05.445
47, 48.

1092
00:51:05.445 --> 00:51:06.350
>> 47, yup.

1093
00:51:06.350 --> 00:51:08.370
>> So right there, and it's a /29.

1094
00:51:08.370 --> 00:51:09.368
We have to know that.

1095
00:51:11.794 --> 00:51:15.675
Administrator is working with
the 192.168.4.0 network,

1096
00:51:15.675 --> 00:51:18.139
which has been subnetted with a /26 mask.

1097
00:51:19.140 --> 00:51:20.970
Okay, this is a good question.

1098
00:51:20.970 --> 00:51:21.920
Be careful here.

1099
00:51:21.920 --> 00:51:23.390
Read this carefully.

1100
00:51:23.390 --> 00:51:27.180
Which two addresses can be assigned
to host within the same subnet?

1101
00:51:28.230 --> 00:51:30.390
So now you gotta know your block sizes.

1102
00:51:30.390 --> 00:51:33.130
Which two hosts listed here
are in the same subnet?

1103
00:51:40.675 --> 00:51:42.789
Actually, there's a few that
are in the same subnet, but

1104
00:51:42.789 --> 00:51:43.790
which two can be assigned?

1105
00:51:43.790 --> 00:51:44.780
Let me read it carefully.

1106
00:51:44.780 --> 00:51:47.978
Which two addresses can be assigned
to hosts within the same subnet?

1107
00:51:52.415 --> 00:51:59.473
>> [LAUGH] 67 and 125.

1108
00:51:59.473 --> 00:52:00.693
>> I believe he's right.

1109
00:52:00.693 --> 00:52:04.416
>> [LAUGH]
>> So the problem with this guy here is,

1110
00:52:04.416 --> 00:52:10.440
it's a /26, so
our subnets are 0, 64, 128, 192.

1111
00:52:10.440 --> 00:52:14.000
These guys both might be in the 0 subnet,
but this is a broadcast address.

1112
00:52:15.190 --> 00:52:19.306
And the answer I guess, what can be
assigned, that makes this answer wrong.

1113
00:52:19.306 --> 00:52:22.394
128 and 132, this guy is a subnet.

1114
00:52:22.394 --> 00:52:24.646
128's always a subnet.

1115
00:52:24.646 --> 00:52:25.993
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right?

1116
00:52:25.993 --> 00:52:31.049
So 65 and 64, right,
because 127 is my broadcast.

1117
00:52:31.049 --> 00:52:33.824
65 to 126.

1118
00:52:33.824 --> 00:52:38.690
Okay, so the answer is 67 and 125.

1119
00:52:38.690 --> 00:52:40.000
Nice.

1120
00:52:40.000 --> 00:52:43.191
Thought I had, right.

1121
00:52:43.191 --> 00:52:47.285
We gotta go into our next session, so
that'll do it for our Class Cs, guys.

1122
00:52:47.285 --> 00:52:50.392
[SOUND] Hey, how do you feel?

1123
00:52:50.392 --> 00:52:51.217
Awesome, Todd.

1124
00:52:51.217 --> 00:52:52.366
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's great!

1125
00:52:52.366 --> 00:52:54.200
>> [LAUGH] That's great.

1126
00:52:54.200 --> 00:52:55.244
Glad to hear it.

1127
00:52:55.244 --> 00:52:56.069
What about you, Ronnie?

1128
00:52:56.069 --> 00:52:56.892
How are you feeling?

1129
00:52:56.892 --> 00:52:58.727
>> I'm feeling challenged, now.

1130
00:52:58.727 --> 00:52:59.727
>> Good.

1131
00:52:59.727 --> 00:53:01.351
Always good.

1132
00:53:01.351 --> 00:53:02.397
>> In this episode,

1133
00:53:02.397 --> 00:53:07.229
Todd took us through the advantage here
of learning how to subnet easily, right?

1134
00:53:07.229 --> 00:53:09.623
>> Very easily.
>> Getting away from the idea of having to

1135
00:53:09.623 --> 00:53:10.599
learn the binary.

1136
00:53:10.599 --> 00:53:13.933
Making sure, of course, that you
understand the method that he's been using

1137
00:53:13.933 --> 00:53:17.300
that has really helped him to be
successful, and helped him to get quicker.

1138
00:53:17.300 --> 00:53:20.110
And the idea on the exam,
of course, is fairly simple.

1139
00:53:20.110 --> 00:53:24.260
We need to know these concepts because
there is no time for you to sit down and

1140
00:53:24.260 --> 00:53:27.560
think that you can write out the binary
bits, and get ready to answer those

1141
00:53:27.560 --> 00:53:31.660
questions, and answer them correctly, and
finish the entire exam at the same time.

1142
00:53:31.660 --> 00:53:34.540
So take a look at this
particular video over and

1143
00:53:34.540 --> 00:53:37.200
over again until it
really does make sense.

1144
00:53:37.200 --> 00:53:38.670
Make sure you learn how
to count by sixteen.

1145
00:53:38.670 --> 00:53:39.830
Obviously, I can't.

1146
00:53:39.830 --> 00:53:40.678
But overall

1147
00:53:40.678 --> 00:53:41.420
>> [LAUGH]
>> make sure

1148
00:53:41.420 --> 00:53:43.070
>> You're better at it now, though.

1149
00:53:43.070 --> 00:53:45.340
>> Yeah, make sure you learn
how to do that as well, and

1150
00:53:45.340 --> 00:53:46.120
that's going to help out.

1151
00:53:46.120 --> 00:53:48.910
And what we did is we really
focused in on the Class Cs.

1152
00:53:48.910 --> 00:53:52.535
But we do have more subnetting to come,
so make sure you also stay tuned for

1153
00:53:52.535 --> 00:53:53.651
that episode as well.

1154
00:53:53.651 --> 00:53:55.640
And that's a great place for
us to go ahead and sign off.

1155
00:53:55.640 --> 00:53:57.404
For ITProTV,
>> Yes.

1156
00:53:57.404 --> 00:53:58.948
>> I've been your host, Ronnie Wong.

1157
00:53:58.948 --> 00:54:00.005
>> And that was a lot of fun.

1158
00:54:00.005 --> 00:54:01.073
Thank you for joining me.

1159
00:54:01.073 --> 00:54:02.292
My name is Todd Lamley.

1160
00:54:02.292 --> 00:54:07.308
>> And we'll see you right here for
more CCENT.

1161
00:54:07.308 --> 00:54:14.720
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Mr. Lammle continues to help prepare for the new exam by demonstrating subnetting on Class B networks.  He points out where confusion and problems occur doing subnetting on larger address space.  Using multiple examples, Todd demonstrates the most like type of subnetting questions that a CCENT candidate will tend to face.  He also emphasizes the necessity of this skill without doing binary conversion or ANDing if you’re pursuing the CCENT.
episodes.title: Class B Subnetting
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2

Welcome to another exciting
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.640 --> 00:00:19.620
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and today
we're taking a look at ICND1 content and

4
00:00:19.620 --> 00:00:21.530
getting ready for that exam.

5
00:00:21.530 --> 00:00:25.000
And to help us actually focus in
on that exam content we have Mr.

6
00:00:25.000 --> 00:00:26.790
Todd Lammie here in our studios.

7
00:00:26.790 --> 00:00:28.860
Thank you for being here,
glad you're back.

8
00:00:28.860 --> 00:00:31.830
>> Great, thank you so much,
it's great to be back here this morning.

9
00:00:31.830 --> 00:00:35.930
Now we're gonna head right into
the objectives for subneting and

10
00:00:35.930 --> 00:00:38.640
then we're gonna head VLSM summarization.

11
00:00:38.640 --> 00:00:42.120
But we're gonna start with
class B this morning.

12
00:00:42.120 --> 00:00:43.770
So if you're just joining us and

13
00:00:43.770 --> 00:00:47.340
you missed yesterday where we were
doing class C introduction to TCPIP,

14
00:00:47.340 --> 00:00:50.820
we did ethernet and we spent all day
on internetworking and what not.

15
00:00:50.820 --> 00:00:54.810
But we're going to hit class B now so
I'm going to jump ahead like hey,

16
00:00:54.810 --> 00:00:55.350
you've been here okay.

17
00:00:55.350 --> 00:00:57.960
So if you're just joining us this
morning you might have to go back and

18
00:00:57.960 --> 00:00:59.350
review the videos.

19
00:00:59.350 --> 00:01:02.398
All right so listen let's go ahead,
I'm gonna head towards the videos,

20
00:01:02.398 --> 00:01:04.430
towards the objectives.

21
00:01:04.430 --> 00:01:06.440
One of the things you
guys gotta understand is,

22
00:01:06.440 --> 00:01:11.890
you have to be able to subnet, no ifs ands
or buts, in your head, in zero seconds.

23
00:01:11.890 --> 00:01:14.430
All right, so
time has gone where you can, you know,

24
00:01:14.430 --> 00:01:17.800
I just don't understand classes where they
say well, you and and or, and do all.

25
00:01:17.800 --> 00:01:21.620
Forget it, you won't be able to
get your CSNA and your all right?

26
00:01:21.620 --> 00:01:22.450
So, we're not gonna do any of that.

27
00:01:22.450 --> 00:01:26.130
We're gonna take off from where we left
yesterday, but we're using my block sizes,

28
00:01:26.130 --> 00:01:28.580
count, we're gonna see a slash
notation turn into a mass,

29
00:01:28.580 --> 00:01:30.300
turn into a block size, we're done, okay?

30
00:01:30.300 --> 00:01:32.482
Now, we're gonna turn that
into Class B guys, you ready?

31
00:01:32.482 --> 00:01:34.615
And then again, as in yesterday,
we're gonna test Ronnie.

32
00:01:34.615 --> 00:01:37.270
He's gonna be a subnetting expert
by the time I'm done here.

33
00:01:37.270 --> 00:01:39.522
All right, Class B /17, my friends.

34
00:01:39.522 --> 00:01:45.935
We have to know our slash
terminology right, /8 through /30.

35
00:01:45.935 --> 00:01:50.301
So we understand there is a /31 but
it's not covered in the CCNA, so

36
00:01:50.301 --> 00:01:51.660
we only go to /30.

37
00:01:51.660 --> 00:01:54.726
That being said, Class B subletting, /17.

38
00:01:54.726 --> 00:01:58.094
So notice this is my 172.16,

39
00:01:58.094 --> 00:02:00.940
this is a Class B, RFC-
>> 1918.

40
00:02:00.940 --> 00:02:03.850
>> 1918, thank you, address, right.

41
00:02:03.850 --> 00:02:05.700
So that's one of my private addresses.

42
00:02:05.700 --> 00:02:10.320
Now if I look at,
here's my default mask, 255.255 and

43
00:02:10.320 --> 00:02:13.920
then my mask here in
the third octet is a 128.

44
00:02:13.920 --> 00:02:17.110
Well, we know that we start
subnetting right here.

45
00:02:17.110 --> 00:02:20.960
So how many bits am I using here, Ronnie,
to subnet with this first subnet mask?

46
00:02:20.960 --> 00:02:24.230
>> You're doing all 17, or
you're adding in the extra one?

47
00:02:24.230 --> 00:02:27.170
>> Yeah, just one subnet bit,
cuz these are my default bits.

48
00:02:27.170 --> 00:02:30.440
I can't change those, obviously,
you can never change those or

49
00:02:30.440 --> 00:02:33.660
anything until we get to summarization,
then we'll screw with them.

50
00:02:33.660 --> 00:02:34.580
>> [LAUGH]
>> But for now,

51
00:02:34.580 --> 00:02:36.725
we have one subnet bit, right?

52
00:02:36.725 --> 00:02:41.003
We list that down here,
one subnet bit, and this gives us,

53
00:02:41.003 --> 00:02:42.810
how many host bits here?

54
00:02:42.810 --> 00:02:46.790
We have eight here and
seven here, that's a lot.

55
00:02:46.790 --> 00:02:48.230
The answer is who cares right.

56
00:02:48.230 --> 00:02:49.050
You have a lot of hosts,

57
00:02:49.050 --> 00:02:53.338
more than you can implement on any host
ever in this galaxy, world, whatever.

58
00:02:53.338 --> 00:02:57.750
All right so, when we were in Class C,
we had a 128 mask and

59
00:02:57.750 --> 00:03:00.630
let's talk about this for a second so
we don't det all stressed out.

60
00:03:00.630 --> 00:03:04.270
A 128 mask is the block size of 128.

61
00:03:04.270 --> 00:03:09.360
And starting at zero,
which were we always count.

62
00:03:09.360 --> 00:03:12.240
Remember we talked about
the IP subnet zero yesterday.

63
00:03:12.240 --> 00:03:15.320
Zero, and then we count increase of
our block size until we get to 256.

64
00:03:15.320 --> 00:03:20.000
So might subnet would be zero,
the next subnet 128 and then 256, right?

65
00:03:20.000 --> 00:03:23.690
And we know we can't use 256, but
I just can't, I've been thorough here.

66
00:03:23.690 --> 00:03:28.980
Zero is my first subnet and next subnet
is 128, and then the broadcast address of

67
00:03:28.980 --> 00:03:33.200
my zero subnet is always the number right
before the next subnet, in this case, 127.

68
00:03:33.200 --> 00:03:35.801
And yes, I know there's a fourth octet,
hang in there.

69
00:03:35.801 --> 00:03:38.466
>> [LAUGH]
>> 128, the next increment is 256 so

70
00:03:38.466 --> 00:03:39.441
I put a 255 here.

71
00:03:39.441 --> 00:03:42.850
This is my third octet information.

72
00:03:42.850 --> 00:03:45.770
So I'm taking the same subnets
that I had in the fourth octet,

73
00:03:45.770 --> 00:03:49.110
moving them to the third octet, right?

74
00:03:49.110 --> 00:03:50.890
And I have the same exact numbers.

75
00:03:50.890 --> 00:03:52.490
So that's why this method is so great.

76
00:03:52.490 --> 00:03:55.610
Because once we get our method down,
doing Class C,

77
00:03:55.610 --> 00:03:59.760
we're not all stressed out or
anxietized, we move into the second and

78
00:03:59.760 --> 00:04:01.710
third octet and
the numbers are exactly the same.

79
00:04:01.710 --> 00:04:03.690
But there's one small difference.

80
00:04:03.690 --> 00:04:06.380
Easy, small difference and
that is in the fourth octet.

81
00:04:06.380 --> 00:04:09.570
If we look at this, this is a zero here.

82
00:04:09.570 --> 00:04:13.350
Which means we have zero subnet bits,
zero subnet bits.

83
00:04:13.350 --> 00:04:17.010
So, Ronnie, if I want to get a network
address, what do I do to host bits?

84
00:04:17.010 --> 00:04:18.780
>> To get the network address?

85
00:04:18.780 --> 00:04:20.490
>> Yes.
>> We normally zero them all

86
00:04:20.490 --> 00:04:21.150
out on the host bits.

87
00:04:21.150 --> 00:04:24.500
>> Yes, we turn them all off is
the answer, he is correct again.

88
00:04:24.500 --> 00:04:26.300
So that's your first one today.

89
00:04:26.300 --> 00:04:27.345
>> Thank you.
>> One for one so far.

90
00:04:27.345 --> 00:04:29.354
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's two, cuz you got the block side.

91
00:04:29.354 --> 00:04:33.318
Zero, right, is my network
address all hosts bits off, so

92
00:04:33.318 --> 00:04:35.810
I put a zero in the fourth octet.

93
00:04:35.810 --> 00:04:37.690
And then Ronnie, if I'm looking for
my broadcast address,

94
00:04:37.690 --> 00:04:38.940
what do I do with host bits now?

95
00:04:38.940 --> 00:04:39.640
>> We turn them all on.

96
00:04:39.640 --> 00:04:41.430
>> We turn them all on so
when the fourth octet,

97
00:04:41.430 --> 00:04:44.160
since this is a zero and they're all
host bits, then that would be a 255.

98
00:04:44.160 --> 00:04:47.210
So if we look down here,
actually, where I wrote it out,

99
00:04:47.210 --> 00:04:50.950
third octet is my same answers for
my block size of 128 here.

100
00:04:50.950 --> 00:04:52.306
And my block is here, but whatever.

101
00:04:52.306 --> 00:04:57.200
128, so zero's my first subnet, the next
subnet's 128, a 127 in the third octet.

102
00:04:57.200 --> 00:05:00.520
Remember these were the same
answers in the fourth octet

103
00:05:00.520 --> 00:05:03.330
move them to the third octet,
add a zero and a .255 at the end.

104
00:05:03.330 --> 00:05:05.010
So this isn't hard.

105
00:05:05.010 --> 00:05:08.700
Again, I took the same answers I had
before, moved them to the octet, that's

106
00:05:08.700 --> 00:05:13.470
interesting, in this case the third one,
and then added my host bits on the right.

107
00:05:13.470 --> 00:05:18.700
It's either one or two octets,
in this case one, added .0 and a .255.

108
00:05:18.700 --> 00:05:21.549
There is no other answer, at .0 and .285.

109
00:05:21.549 --> 00:05:24.220
Now when we start subnetting into
the fourth octet with class A or

110
00:05:24.220 --> 00:05:25.740
B then we'll come up
with different answers.

111
00:05:25.740 --> 00:05:27.548
But we're not doing that now,
so let's not jump ahead.

112
00:05:27.548 --> 00:05:29.410
.0 and .285 is always my answer.

113
00:05:29.410 --> 00:05:33.115
So if my next subnet is 128,
then what's my true subnet and

114
00:05:33.115 --> 00:05:35.985
my true broadcast address for
the next subnet?

115
00:05:37.982 --> 00:05:40.884
