episodes.description: In this episode, Cisco expert, Todd Lammle reviews the basic security concepts and using ACLs to help secure Cisco devices.  He explains the difference between the standard and extended access lists as well as named ACLs.  He discusses the basics of where access lists are applied and how to configure them with the most specific filtering statements first then more generic statements toward the bottom of the list.  He emphasizes that ACLs use inverse masks and not subnet masks.  Todd demonstrates creating and applying the act on a router’s interface and VTY lines using access-list and access-class, respectively.
episodes.title: Security
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.991 --> 00:00:14.594
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.594 --> 00:00:20.350
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and today we're
continuing on with ICND1 objectives.

4
00:00:20.350 --> 00:00:23.290
Getting ready for that new Cisco
exam that's just been released.

5
00:00:23.290 --> 00:00:24.710
And in our studios today we have Mr.

6
00:00:24.710 --> 00:00:28.410
Tom Lammle to help guide us through
those exam objectives and those hurdles.

7
00:00:28.410 --> 00:00:30.050
Welcome back to our studios.

8
00:00:30.050 --> 00:00:31.122
>> Thanks Ronnie, it's good to be here.

9
00:00:31.122 --> 00:00:36.060
We're gonna cover security and really with
CCENT, there's a few things we'll cover at

10
00:00:36.060 --> 00:00:40.060
first to explain very simple security,
and then it's just access lists.

11
00:00:40.060 --> 00:00:44.850
Now the new CCENT, I gotta tell you,
only covers standard access lists.

12
00:00:44.850 --> 00:00:46.830
Which is odd, right?

13
00:00:46.830 --> 00:00:51.910
In ICD2 though, it covers troubleshooting
with extended access list but

14
00:00:51.910 --> 00:00:55.960
they don't cover the material in their new
course of in their objectives or anything.

15
00:00:55.960 --> 00:00:57.540
It's just inside troubleshooting.

16
00:00:57.540 --> 00:01:01.188
So I'm gonna cover standard access
lists here and access list for

17
00:01:01.188 --> 00:01:05.030
our VTY lines, those are the big
objectives for the CCENT.

18
00:01:05.030 --> 00:01:08.538
In my book, I do cover extended access
lists that you want to read before you tie

19
00:01:08.538 --> 00:01:10.420
cuz that's where those are covered.

20
00:01:10.420 --> 00:01:11.580
Let's go ahead and take a look and

21
00:01:11.580 --> 00:01:14.788
we'll get right started in to our
introduction to security here.

22
00:01:14.788 --> 00:01:19.060
All right so, to protect, let's go
through a couple of foundational things.

23
00:01:19.060 --> 00:01:20.146
Protect network device.

24
00:01:20.146 --> 00:01:22.810
Okay, these are our CCENT objective.

25
00:01:22.810 --> 00:01:25.640
Or use a firewall to restrict access
from the outside to network devices,

26
00:01:25.640 --> 00:01:26.750
that's obvious.

27
00:01:26.750 --> 00:01:29.620
Now instead of using telnet,
we're gonna use SSH, right?

28
00:01:30.690 --> 00:01:36.420
And secure copy protocol instead of just
clear text FTP, something like that.

29
00:01:36.420 --> 00:01:39.140
And then the most important here,
physically secure

30
00:01:39.140 --> 00:01:43.510
network equipment from potential access
by unauthorized individuals, right?

31
00:01:43.510 --> 00:01:46.530
Those are our three bullet points
on why we need the security.

32
00:01:46.530 --> 00:01:50.620
Now, the most common attack is
typically denial of service, right?

33
00:01:50.620 --> 00:01:57.570
Denial of service, DoS, right?

34
00:01:57.570 --> 00:02:04.600
This is where a host sends a sync packet
65,000 times, uses up all the open ports.

35
00:02:04.600 --> 00:02:08.130
And then that guy is not able to
use that IP address again, and

36
00:02:08.130 --> 00:02:10.010
be able to answer on that port.

37
00:02:10.010 --> 00:02:12.730
We're gonna sync,
he sends a sync out but we never answer.

38
00:02:12.730 --> 00:02:14.790
That's just a basic denial of service.

39
00:02:14.790 --> 00:02:16.975
There's also some distributed
denial of service.

40
00:02:16.975 --> 00:02:20.284
That's more common, where I have
thousands of hosts attacking a server.

41
00:02:20.284 --> 00:02:22.846
It's harder to do today on Amazon and
stuff like that, but

42
00:02:22.846 --> 00:02:24.530
people do it when they get mad at them.

43
00:02:24.530 --> 00:02:26.597
It just takes a really
big coordinated effort.

44
00:02:26.597 --> 00:02:28.927
But with Anonymous and some of those guys,

45
00:02:28.927 --> 00:02:32.700
they can do a huge distributed
denial of service attacks.

46
00:02:32.700 --> 00:02:36.397
Now to be able to stop that, we're gonna
use something called an IPS today,

47
00:02:36.397 --> 00:02:38.390
intrusion prevention system.

48
00:02:38.390 --> 00:02:40.550
We typically don't use IDS.

49
00:02:40.550 --> 00:02:43.770
I do know people that still
take their IPS systems.

50
00:02:43.770 --> 00:02:45.320
The Cisco Next Generation IPS,

51
00:02:45.320 --> 00:02:50.240
Next Generation Firewall, which we call
fire power a lot, provides all this.

52
00:02:50.240 --> 00:02:52.220
They put it into what's
called monitor only mode, and

53
00:02:52.220 --> 00:02:53.870
that is really run as an IDS.

54
00:02:53.870 --> 00:02:56.670
We don't really even use the term
IDS in the industry anymore, why?

55
00:02:56.670 --> 00:03:00.570
Because IPS now works very well,
it's just considered a bump in the wire.

56
00:03:00.570 --> 00:03:04.420
Gives us everything that we need to
work in real time to stop threats.

57
00:03:04.420 --> 00:03:06.520
However, if you don't take
it out of monitor only mode,

58
00:03:06.520 --> 00:03:07.680
you're really just an IDS.

59
00:03:09.820 --> 00:03:13.930
There was that commercial in that guy's
in the bank, and these robbers come in.

60
00:03:13.930 --> 00:03:15.490
And the lady's like, what are you doing?

61
00:03:15.490 --> 00:03:16.250
There's a robbery.

62
00:03:16.250 --> 00:03:17.700
He goes well, I'm just here to tell you.

63
00:03:17.700 --> 00:03:18.570
>> A monitoring service.

64
00:03:18.570 --> 00:03:21.160
>> I'm just here to monitor and
tell you if there's a robbery.

65
00:03:21.160 --> 00:03:21.865
There's a robbery.

66
00:03:21.865 --> 00:03:23.100
>> [LAUGH]
>> And it was just like

67
00:03:23.100 --> 00:03:25.540
that's what IDS is, useless.

68
00:03:25.540 --> 00:03:27.030
That guy was useless to her.

69
00:03:27.030 --> 00:03:29.250
She's down there getting robbed.

70
00:03:29.250 --> 00:03:31.930
He told her after the fact
they got a robbery.

71
00:03:31.930 --> 00:03:32.890
That's what IDS does.

72
00:03:32.890 --> 00:03:36.900
To me, I always thought it mocked me
because I'd set it up at my customers'

73
00:03:36.900 --> 00:03:37.490
and it would page me.

74
00:03:37.490 --> 00:03:38.870
That's how long ago I did this.

75
00:03:38.870 --> 00:03:40.840
It would page me and
basically tell me, hey, man.

76
00:03:40.840 --> 00:03:42.640
I hope you updated your resume.

77
00:03:42.640 --> 00:03:44.390
Cuz a resume-generating
event just occurred.

78
00:03:44.390 --> 00:03:45.380
I didn't do anything about it.

79
00:03:45.380 --> 00:03:46.630
I'm just letting you know.

80
00:03:46.630 --> 00:03:48.780
All right, that's why we don't use IPS.

81
00:03:48.780 --> 00:03:50.350
IPS stops in real time.

82
00:03:51.760 --> 00:03:53.590
Why use access control lists?

83
00:03:53.590 --> 00:03:56.820
Well, the answer is,
we're going to use them today.

84
00:03:56.820 --> 00:03:58.620
Now, we used to use them
as our full security, but

85
00:03:58.620 --> 00:03:59.960
we're not gonna do that anymore.

86
00:03:59.960 --> 00:04:03.227
We have to have the next gen, whether
you're using Cisco or somebody else,

87
00:04:03.227 --> 00:04:04.871
you need a next generation firewall.

88
00:04:04.871 --> 00:04:07.038
You need a next generation IPS.

89
00:04:07.038 --> 00:04:09.240
It's the only way to stop.

90
00:04:09.240 --> 00:04:14.350
Cuz you're gonna get malware, which is
gonna give you ransomware or worse.

91
00:04:14.350 --> 00:04:16.245
All sorts of issues.

92
00:04:16.245 --> 00:04:17.600
Anyways, why use access control lists?

93
00:04:17.600 --> 00:04:22.169
Well, Bob in sales is trying to get into
the finance department to find out how

94
00:04:22.169 --> 00:04:23.869
much money everyone makes.

95
00:04:23.869 --> 00:04:26.570
Don't think that people don't this,
they do this all the time.

96
00:04:26.570 --> 00:04:29.058
Everyone wants to know how much
money everyone else makes.

97
00:04:29.058 --> 00:04:32.124
I mean, this is a great place for
an access list and

98
00:04:32.124 --> 00:04:35.190
I've done this all the time
because this guy Bob,

99
00:04:35.190 --> 00:04:40.393
that jerk from was always trying to get
into finance and to get information.

100
00:04:40.393 --> 00:04:42.501
It wasn't as hard to break in back then so

101
00:04:42.501 --> 00:04:46.290
a simple access list Bob
from getting into finance.

102
00:04:46.290 --> 00:04:50.730
So we use it for our Internet, intranet,
right, inside stuff like that.

103
00:04:50.730 --> 00:04:55.610
Do we use and access this on our
outside egress, sure, we block.

104
00:04:55.610 --> 00:05:00.170
Hey no RFC 1918s coming in, none of
our local addresses should be coming

105
00:05:00.170 --> 00:05:03.570
in from the outside, and just, but
it's a big picture there, right?

106
00:05:03.570 --> 00:05:05.240
And it's great to have that.

107
00:05:05.240 --> 00:05:08.810
And then on the inside, we can just
micro manage users and stuff like that.

108
00:05:08.810 --> 00:05:10.920
The idea is we don't really
want to use access lists and

109
00:05:10.920 --> 00:05:12.270
we'll talk about that more coming up.

110
00:05:13.790 --> 00:05:16.403
So here's the idea what you
need to remember though,

111
00:05:16.403 --> 00:05:19.898
let's say that I was in this router and
I telnetted to this router here.

112
00:05:19.898 --> 00:05:22.940
Let's say though I had an access list
that said blocked telnet on this that I

113
00:05:22.940 --> 00:05:24.500
couldn't telnet out of this router.

114
00:05:24.500 --> 00:05:28.660
It would still work because I'm
telnetting from that router.

115
00:05:28.660 --> 00:05:30.930
So it has to be passing
through the router for

116
00:05:30.930 --> 00:05:33.000
an access list to take effect, all right?

117
00:05:33.000 --> 00:05:36.280
Not, if the traffic's generated at
the router, it's not gonna take effect,

118
00:05:36.280 --> 00:05:37.710
we can see that later.

119
00:05:37.710 --> 00:05:40.440
Now we're gonna use some different
types of access list, and

120
00:05:40.440 --> 00:05:41.830
they're configured two different ways.

121
00:05:41.830 --> 00:05:44.870
There's standard,
which only, this is a total,

122
00:05:44.870 --> 00:05:46.830
I can't even believe this
was the only objectives.

123
00:05:46.830 --> 00:05:48.155
When I saw that, I was like,
you gotta be kidding me.

124
00:05:48.155 --> 00:05:52.132
We only filter on source,
haven't used these in a decade or more.

125
00:05:52.132 --> 00:05:53.569
You don't really want to use it.

126
00:05:53.569 --> 00:05:55.214
They're very broad.

127
00:05:55.214 --> 00:05:59.890
If you're the source address, block it.

128
00:05:59.890 --> 00:06:01.820
We only filter on source.

129
00:06:01.820 --> 00:06:06.680
When we come down to extended, we filter
on source and destination, on minimum.

130
00:06:06.680 --> 00:06:09.890
So the minute you type in an extended
number and you say I'm using an extended

131
00:06:09.890 --> 00:06:13.620
number, it says, okay, you need to type
in a source and a destination address.

132
00:06:14.630 --> 00:06:16.940
On the standard, again, are you Bob?

133
00:06:16.940 --> 00:06:17.822
You're denied.

134
00:06:17.822 --> 00:06:20.480
Well, but I'm trying to go do
something valid, too bad, your denied,

135
00:06:20.480 --> 00:06:22.820
you're Bob, you're out.

136
00:06:22.820 --> 00:06:25.610
Now in this case here on extended,
source and destination,

137
00:06:25.610 --> 00:06:26.990
are you Bob trying to
go to the finance LAN,

138
00:06:26.990 --> 00:06:29.530
you're denied, are you trying to go
somewhere else, go ahead, right?

139
00:06:29.530 --> 00:06:31.519
So right away that gives us an advantage,
but it can do more.

140
00:06:31.519 --> 00:06:36.329
Source and destination protocols,
the protocol field never clear header,

141
00:06:36.329 --> 00:06:38.700
port numbers at the transport layer.

142
00:06:38.700 --> 00:06:42.620
So you say are you Bob,
are you trying to the finance LAN and

143
00:06:42.620 --> 00:06:47.860
you're trying to get to the HR server,
or to a server and get HR information?

144
00:06:47.860 --> 00:06:48.760
You're permitted.

145
00:06:48.760 --> 00:06:53.300
Are you trying to FTP into
the finance server to steal stuff?

146
00:06:53.300 --> 00:06:53.980
Then you're denied.

147
00:06:53.980 --> 00:06:55.639
We can be very specific there, right?

148
00:06:55.639 --> 00:06:59.458
So we can let Bob still go into
the finance LAN and get HR information but

149
00:06:59.458 --> 00:07:00.315
nothing else.

150
00:07:00.315 --> 00:07:03.682
Okay, two methods used to identify,
we can use numbered or named,

151
00:07:03.682 --> 00:07:05.830
we're gonna use them both in here.

152
00:07:05.830 --> 00:07:09.630
Didn't really use named too
much in the past objectives,

153
00:07:09.630 --> 00:07:10.770
now we're gonna use named.

154
00:07:10.770 --> 00:07:14.310
They're really the same thing,
both of these are very simple.

155
00:07:14.310 --> 00:07:16.820
Now let's go through some configuration
guidelines that are important for

156
00:07:16.820 --> 00:07:17.880
your objectives.

157
00:07:17.880 --> 00:07:20.500
I know we're doing some lecture and
some PowerPoints but hang in there and

158
00:07:20.500 --> 00:07:22.510
we'll get some configuration in a second.

159
00:07:22.510 --> 00:07:25.390
Standard or
extended indicates what can be filtered.

160
00:07:26.460 --> 00:07:29.305
We also have IPv6 access
list coming up as well.

161
00:07:29.305 --> 00:07:33.419
Not in this section, but
in we'll do IPv6 access list.

162
00:07:33.419 --> 00:07:35.365
Only one ACL per interface.

163
00:07:35.365 --> 00:07:38.957
So I don't create a bunch of ACLs.

164
00:07:38.957 --> 00:07:40.832
Access list 1, deny Bob.

165
00:07:40.832 --> 00:07:42.312
Access list 2, permit Sally.

166
00:07:42.312 --> 00:07:44.110
Access list 3, deny Jordan.

167
00:07:44.110 --> 00:07:47.500
No, access list 1,
access list 1, access list 1.

168
00:07:47.500 --> 00:07:51.019
Right, we use the same number, create
a bunch of group statements in the same

169
00:07:51.019 --> 00:07:53.526
group and then we apply access
list 1 to an interface.

170
00:07:53.526 --> 00:07:57.886
Can only apply one per protocol
per interface per direction.

171
00:07:57.886 --> 00:08:00.458
The order of statements control testing.

172
00:08:00.458 --> 00:08:02.445
Now for example, this is pretty important.

173
00:08:02.445 --> 00:08:08.530
Because, let's say that Bob was in sales
and I wanted to permit everyone but Bob.

174
00:08:08.530 --> 00:08:11.409
So if I sat there and
said, access list 10.

175
00:08:11.409 --> 00:08:16.790
Whatever, It's saying standard,
because if I come back here for a second.

176
00:08:16.790 --> 00:08:18.410
Numbered one to 99 for standard, so

177
00:08:18.410 --> 00:08:21.360
you're going to see me using
those numbers a lot, 1 to 99.

178
00:08:21.360 --> 00:08:28.030
Access list ten permit sales,
if that's my first line.

179
00:08:28.030 --> 00:08:29.800
Permit sales, okay.

180
00:08:29.800 --> 00:08:32.510
The next line says,
access list ten deny bob.

181
00:08:33.520 --> 00:08:34.590
Is bob denied?

182
00:08:34.590 --> 00:08:38.230
Absolutely not, because bob
matches that first line, right.

183
00:08:38.230 --> 00:08:40.610
So the point is, as soon as you
match a line in access list,

184
00:08:40.610 --> 00:08:42.650
it's acted on, you're permitted or
denied period.

185
00:08:42.650 --> 00:08:47.890
You don't see the next line, so my line
would have to be access ten denied Bob.

186
00:08:47.890 --> 00:08:49.840
Next line permit everybody else, right.

187
00:08:49.840 --> 00:08:52.380
Deny Bob first and then,
permit everything else.

188
00:08:52.380 --> 00:08:56.130
You also need to remember that,
if I did this, deny Bob, deny George,

189
00:08:56.130 --> 00:08:58.620
deny Sally and applied it to an interface.

190
00:08:58.620 --> 00:09:00.590
You might as well just go
unplug that interface,

191
00:09:00.590 --> 00:09:03.600
because the next line by default,
is denial.

192
00:09:03.600 --> 00:09:04.770
Deny any,

193
00:09:04.770 --> 00:09:08.990
everyone's automatically denied as soon as
you apply an access-list to an interface.

194
00:09:08.990 --> 00:09:10.250
Everything is denied.

195
00:09:11.690 --> 00:09:13.840
So if you don't have at
least one permit statement,

196
00:09:13.840 --> 00:09:16.650
just go shut down the interface,
it would be easier, all right.

197
00:09:16.650 --> 00:09:20.410
Now remember,
when we're placing a standard access list,

198
00:09:20.410 --> 00:09:22.010
we're going to place it
closer to the destination.

199
00:09:22.010 --> 00:09:24.720
And the reason why,
if I said access list 10 deny Bob,

200
00:09:24.720 --> 00:09:27.500
and that's a good access list.

201
00:09:27.500 --> 00:09:29.530
I guess,
if I put that close to the source,

202
00:09:29.530 --> 00:09:34.810
then Bob's stuck at home where we want Bob
to get places but not on the finance LAN.

203
00:09:34.810 --> 00:09:37.120
So, I'd have to go all the way
to the finance LAN to deny,

204
00:09:37.120 --> 00:09:39.480
to put Bob on that interface.

205
00:09:39.480 --> 00:09:41.640
All right,
if I put it closer to where he's at,

206
00:09:41.640 --> 00:09:43.400
then I'm denying him from
getting to the internet.

207
00:09:43.400 --> 00:09:47.880
Or to the sales LAN where we want him
to go, so standard, they're so limited,

208
00:09:47.880 --> 00:09:49.390
they're a pain.

209
00:09:49.390 --> 00:09:53.920
You really want extended access lists,
but we're going to learn standard.

210
00:09:53.920 --> 00:09:56.600
Now to do that, we have to know
something about called Inverse Masks.

211
00:09:56.600 --> 00:09:59.420
And the reason they created
these ,Aa first you're like wow,

212
00:09:59.420 --> 00:10:02.260
these are really convoluted and
it's true, they are.

213
00:10:02.260 --> 00:10:03.400
But we'll make them pretty simple.

214
00:10:03.400 --> 00:10:05.180
But the reason they created these,

215
00:10:05.180 --> 00:10:07.950
because if you remember when we
were doing the subnetting episodes.

216
00:10:07.950 --> 00:10:10.800
If you saw those, I was talking about
how you couldn't skip bits, and

217
00:10:10.800 --> 00:10:12.450
that way the answers never change.

218
00:10:12.450 --> 00:10:15.250
By not skipping bits, it helped us.

219
00:10:15.250 --> 00:10:20.560
We were able to subnet VLSM and summarize
in our head quickly and efficiently.

220
00:10:20.560 --> 00:10:22.617
Now, you might want to have had to
watch the episode a couple times.

221
00:10:22.617 --> 00:10:23.540
>> [LAUGH]
>> To get that far, but

222
00:10:23.540 --> 00:10:25.230
nonetheless you could have done that.

223
00:10:25.230 --> 00:10:27.590
So in this case here, they said no,
we're goin to do Inverse Masks, so

224
00:10:27.590 --> 00:10:29.440
we can actually skip bits.

225
00:10:29.440 --> 00:10:32.236
This thing gets really
complicated really fast.

226
00:10:32.236 --> 00:10:34.410
We're not going to get anywhere near that.

227
00:10:34.410 --> 00:10:37.980
Neither does the CCNA or
NP exams in any way, shape or form,

228
00:10:37.980 --> 00:10:40.330
do they do a lot of Inverse Masking.

229
00:10:40.330 --> 00:10:44.980
Now in this case here,

All right so let me come back over

vty [LAUGH] Todd, line vty,

Up arrow.

Make sure you go and check out those

Of course, also the other security.

Also focus in, of course, on ICND1 on the

00:39:32.620 --> 00:39:33.816
We know that there's standard,

we know that there's extended

And they can either be numbered or,

783
00:39:39.900 --> 00:39:43.350
Now remember that once you actually learn

there's a second part, of course,

00:39:44.770 --> 00:39:47.700
to access control lists,

786
00:39:47.700 --> 00:39:52.800
When you choose to apply them to

787
00:39:52.800 --> 00:39:57.980
you actually need that access-group

00:39:57.980 --> 00:40:01.880
But if you're gonna do this to

it changes to access-class.

And if you're doing a named access list,

791

And so these configurations are really

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd shows us one of the key technologies that extended the life of IPv4, NAT.  He describes the three types of network address translation: static, dynamic and PAT.  He also demonstrates how to configure each, emphasizing the ip nat inside and ip nat outside ports that must be configured.
episodes.title: Network Address Translation

I was trying to think,

So, anyways, as usual.

But anyway, so, we used to have 200 users

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd focuses in on managing the Cisco IOS. He talks about the configuration register and how to set it.  He also spends some time talking about backing up the IOS and use of ROMMON to help with password recovery as well as setting up remote access to the router through telnet and ssh.
episodes.title: Managing Cisco Internetworking

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd Lammle focuses in on two discovery protocols that help to show the physical connections and layer 2 information of those devices.  Configuring both CDP and LLDP, he explains the differences and similarities between them.  DNS and DHCP are two networking topics that are important and every candidate should be able to configure both on the cisco routers.  Remember that if your dhcp server resides on a different network than the DHCP clients an IP helper address must configured on the router interface facing the clients.
episodes.title: Managing Cisco Internetworking Part 2

00:35:10.680 --> 00:35:15.060

675
00:35:15.060 --> 00:35:18.060
it's gonna send out what's
called a gratuitous ARP, right?

676
00:35:18.060 --> 00:35:22.130
And so what it does it says hey, I got
this address 192.168.20.2 or whatever it

677
00:35:22.130 --> 00:35:26.580
was, and it's gonna ARP for it, right,
and if someone responds it goes, aw man.

678
00:35:26.580 --> 00:35:28.950
It's gonna tell the server hey,
that one's in use.

679
00:35:28.950 --> 00:35:31.870

680
00:35:31.870 --> 00:35:36.060
we'd be able to see that the detection
method was gratuitous ARP.

681
00:35:36.060 --> 00:35:38.410
Now before that even happens though,
the server,

682
00:35:38.410 --> 00:35:42.220
before it sends out an address,
is actually gonna try to ping the address.

683
00:35:42.220 --> 00:35:45.560
The problem with that, and we can
configure that to how many pings it is,

684
00:35:45.560 --> 00:35:49.530
if you ping too much then the DHCP
client request times out.

685
00:35:49.530 --> 00:35:52.320
So it's kind of a, right in the middle-
>> Balance.

686
00:35:52.320 --> 00:35:56.540
>> So about three would be the max because
you need one or two to resolve ARP and

687
00:35:56.540 --> 00:35:57.780
then your third one,
if you don't get it by then,

688
00:35:57.780 --> 00:36:02.440
it's going to hand out the address just
in time before the client expires.

689
00:36:02.440 --> 00:36:03.770

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd shows the common protocol used in troubleshooting interworking.  He emphasizes the importance of setting the correct time for networking devices and it’s use in logging when events happen.  Demonstrating some details of NTP configuration, Todd shows how to verify NTP is working and its stratum levels.  He continues by emphasizing syslog messages and how to get the messages to output to a syslog server and the types of messages.  Other networking tools also was the extended ping command and show commands.  He completes the episode with licensing and how to load the license into the cisco device.
episodes.title: Managing Cisco Internetworking Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd takes a look into the hardware components of the router showing us the different components but also helping us to understand how the router works it’s boot process.  He demonstrates the most common configurations that we would want to see on a router, including, passwords, usernames, banners, interface descriptions as well as saving the configuration to the NVRAM.

episodes.description: In this episode,  Mr. Lammle shows the most common commands that allow us to verify that our router is configured and working.   He emphasizes the need for a candidate to see and use these commands as called for without having to guess at what information each of the show commands provides for the technician.
